The first bus out of Tonbridge groaned past the river, the driver drumming his fingers on the wheel like he was keeping time with something only he could hear. The grey light threw up low shimmers from the Medway, and the swans looked like badly folded napkins dotted along the water. On Quarry Hill Road, the shop shutters shivered awake. One by one: a fishmonger with a fractured green sign, the charity shop that smelt of lavender and dust and bright wool, the carpet place with the display rolled up like the tongues of dragon dogs. On the corner, a half-dead tree scratched a page of sky. You could almost smell toast, if you wanted it enough.

Tom Merriweather walked to work with a key ring like a small planet orbiting his palm. He was thirty-eight and had a face people said was trustworthy when they'd lost something. He had shoulders that sloped like he'd grown used to carrying poles, planks, ladders, children who'd fallen, guilt about leaks. He worked at St. Pilgrim’s Primary, a practical building that never decided if it wanted to be hopeful or petty, and after ten years he could listen to the walls and know which was about to peel.

He talked to the doors. "Morning, you." The doors never answered, but responded in a way, the way a door does: swinging more easily for people who wag fair words at them.

The custodian's cupboard smelt of mop and medicinal soap and yesterday. He clicked the light, listened to the whirr of the fixture warming up—half a second, then the blossom of humming. It sounded, in his better moods, like the beginning of a song. He sang to himself because it made the mops dance and the broom handles softened their hard stares. He had a voice that, to him, seemed to enter a room half a beat before he did.

It was an old song he favoured this morning, something his mum used to hum while shelling peas—Molly Malone, poor girl, or the one about a river that was never the same river twice. He liked the way the vowels lifted like kites and then went slack on their strings. He liked imagining that they could fly to a place where he fit. He ran the mop along the assembly hall like a man sweeping a stage, paused to look at his own reflection in the polished wood and saw one of those faces that can't keep still. He hit a note at the ceiling and held it longer than the light held its breath.

"Again?" Mrs Penney said from the doorway. She was somewhere between stern and soft, and wore shoes that knew where they wanted to go.

Tom straightened, the mop head dangling. "Keeps the acoustics exercised." He tried a joke like he always did.

She smiled with only two thirds of her mouth. "The sound system keeps the acoustics exercised. You've the caretaker's cupboard today. Leaking bleach. And the Year 2 play equipment hasn't come, so be a magician."

He pulled the mop upright like a soldier. "Righto, righto. You want me to build a donkey or a spaceship?"

"Both. It’s Goldilocks in space this year. Budget cuts. And—" She hesitated, turned, decided against whatever she was about to say, then decided for it. "Keep the singing for after three, will you? They're doing tests. And you know some of them complain."

"Who complains?"

"Parents. Mostly. The children like you. Or they like the idea of you." She left on that odd note, and Tom felt an old bruise of embarrassment bloom at his collar.

"You can't shush a river," he murmured. He did not sing again, which was not the same thing as stopping.

He liked the little jobs that nobody noticed. There was a satisfaction in the quiet heroism of a hinge that no longer squeaked. He took the box of screws from the toolbox, lifting handfuls like pistachios, cupping each tiny head between finger and thumb and turning, turning, until it bit and held. He was good at turning until things held. He was less good at knowing when to stop.

At break, a group of boys gathered by the back step and watched him wind the hose onto its reel. The newest one, a small boy with a forehead like a cliff, asked, "Sir, why do your eyes sing when your mouth does?" Which was nonsense strictly speaking, but true in a way Tom liked more.

"You hear with more than your ears," Tom said. "Watches can hear time pass you know."

"That's just ticking," said a sensible boy with a tight mouth.

"Ticking is sighing for machines." Tom winked and the small cliff nodded as if he'd deciphered something.

They asked him to sing. He shook his head toward the staffroom window, where a silhouette moved dangerously like a teacher with opinions, and he sang anyway, but quietly. "When I was one-and-twenty..." The boys leaned in, mown-grass smell, scabby knees, a chorus of the bored and the fervent. Halfway through, the sensible boy giggled and then they all did, a ripple moving through them like a fish. Tom smiled and finished the verse. After they ran away, he looked up to see his own reflection in the staffroom window, mouth open, eyes partly closed. It wasn't pretty. He decided it looked serious.

His phone vibrated like an insect in his pocket at lunch. He ate in the little cafe beyond the station some days, but more often he went to The Oast House, which had learned his name without asking. Kira, who worked the noon shift and wore eyeliner as if it were armour, poured him a pint of lemonade without asking, and placed it in front of him like a truce.

"You singing tonight, Tom?" she asked. She was used to the question stealing the lift from her eyebrows when she saw the way he lit.

"Not formally," he said. "But I will if conjured. I'm thinking of—"

"Please don't say My Way."

"—My Way." He grinned at her as if he had done something clever.

"You know the contest?" Kira nodded at a poster pinned near the back door, where it would attract exactly as much attention as a notice about a missing cat. SOUTH EAST SONG QUEST, it read, a star and musical notes climbing a ladder. Heat from the kitchen had curled one corner. The paper looked as though it was tired of making promises.

Tom's eyes landed like magpies. "Is that—" He got up too quickly and his lemonade sloshed.

"That's old," Kira said over the clink of plates. "Came last year, I think. The bloke never collected the posters. They do a new one every spring. You can go to Tunbridge Wells and stand in a queue and two minutes later they'll tell you what you've got. Or not. It was funny last time. There was a man did Blackbird who sounded like one."

"Blackbird's easy to confuse," Tom said gravely, closer to the paper than any grown man should need to be. The print had been smudged so the dates smudged with it. A tear-off strip had only one ragged number left: 0777something, the rest lost to time or teenagers.

"There's more online," Kira said. "It's always online."

"I don't have the online." He said it lightly, in case it was a confession.

"You don't have the online?" She laughed the way she did, an unexpected delighted sound like dice in a cup. "You don't have a phone?"

"I have a phone. It's a phone that phones. It's... a talking machine."

"Eyes to floor, Granddads," she teased. "Well, maybe you get a leaflet from the library. Or ask Gary. Gary has everything. He's a mole with Wi-Fi."

"I'll ask Gary," he said, pocketing the poster tab, though it lacked the piece a person would need. He liked the feel of torn paper. He liked talismans.

He ate his shepherd's pie in a daze, counted out the coins, and left a chip in neat halves, because leaving a whole would be wasteful, and eating it would be greed. Outside, the afternoon air had taken on that peculiar crispness that happens when a coastal wind gets lost inland. He used the back lane, because it was quicker and because it had a mural that changed every few months, messages painted over messages, an archaeology of spray paint. Today it said YOU ARE GOLD in letters that slumped at the edges. He imagined the mural talking to him when he couldn't sleep. He tried not to imagine the mural telling him something truer: you are brass, you are tin, you are not the thing you think.

When he finished the day, he took the long way home for no reason other than that he wanted to pass the old cinema. He liked the names on the marquee even when they were for films he would never watch. He liked that wishes could be lit, letter by letter, even if they spelt out nothing you’d recognise later. He lived in a bedsit above Finnerty Carpets, with a stovetop that made a sound like a throat clearing when it was ready, and a window that didn't face anywhere useful.

His upstairs neighbour was Mr Dray, who coughed through the floorboards and played the shipping forecast for comfort, low but relentless. If Tom put his ear to the skirting he could hear the shape of it, the hush and swell of weather where he had never been. Sometimes he hummed along. It didn't fit, and that was the point.

The walls were thin enough that you could borrow things from your neighbour without asking, like heat or the scent of burned jam. Tonight he borrowed a sliver of cricket commentary and the smell from Finnerty's of new carpet: plastic and glue and hope that this would be the one that didn't stain. He boiled spaghetti until it surrendered. He wrote his name on a post-it note, because it amused him to imagine a policeman holding it up to his face in a future where he had forgotten. He placed the note on the fridge and looked at it for a while, noticing how the letters hunched like people in a bus shelter.

He tried the number on the poster tab even though it wasn't complete, because he believed in mercy. He dialed 0777 and then the ghost of digits, his thumb hovering over blankness as if he could fill it with wanting. The tone told him to stop being foolish. He laughed at himself and didn't feel silly at all, which is a little worrying if you look at it too hard.

He went downstairs, locking the carpet shop on the way with the key Finnerty had given him for emergencies. Finnerty said he had a face like someone who wouldn't steal, which was both an insult and an honour. The evening had a bruise in it now. He walked along the High Street and turned into the coin laundrette with its neon that made everyone look a little dead. Gary ran the place, sort of. He sat behind the counter with a flat cap and a flat expression and eyes like a caravan site: all of it temporary.

"You look like someone who needs to know the internet," Gary said by way of greeting. "Or a stiff drink. I can only help with one legally."

"Do you know South East Song Quest?" Tom asked, and it pleased him that the name made a pattern in his mouth. ACK. ST. Q. You could sing those letters.

"I know everything that has a forum," Gary said. "And I've had the misfortune of reading one about that. Why?"

"I want to enter," Tom said, which felt like pushing open a door and finding a meadow or a cliff, and then finding out it was a mirror.

Gary typed with two fingers and a solemnity that made the task seem holy. The screen lit his face from below and stole his age. He made noises at the screen, low key exasperations. "All right. There's heats all over Kent. You go and you do your party piece and then people get angry in the comments. Final's at the Assembly Hall in Tunbridge Wells like always. They moved one to Maidstone once and no one stopped going on about it. There's an email address. There's a phone number, but you don't ring it because you'll get a person who needs to be rebooted."

"I'd like to skip the queue," Tom said, as if saying it might make it true. "I'm not really a queuer. I’m a late-comer-and-then-anointed sort."

Gary snorted. "You'll want the wildcard. They do a 'community hero' thing. The kind of person who helps old people with their bags and rescues dogs and then everyone claps regardless of whether he can hold a tune."

Tom looked appropriately saintly. "I rescue chairs. Does that count?"

"Depends on the chair." Gary handed him a pad and a pencil. "Write down your full name, your real one not the one you give girls at the pub, and your mobile and your email and I'll pretend to be you for five minutes and send them your sob story."

"I haven't a sob story," Tom said quickly. There was too much of one to choose from. It wouldn't sort itself in a paragraph. And it wasn't quite sob, besides. It was something with a different weather system.

"Fine. We'll call you The Singing Caretaker and make up the rest. People love a title. Like The Laughing Plumber and The Psychic Fishmonger. We will say... you repair things. And sing."

"I do repair things," Tom said.

Gary wrote. He typed. He clicked. He sucked his teeth like a mechanic negotiating a stubborn part. "Done. They'll either ignore me, or they'll be in a bind and they'll pounce on you because a caretaker is human enough to project decency onto. You'll get your moment. Could be fun. Or a catastrophe, which is also fun."

"Did you ever sing?" Tom asked, because he couldn't imagine Gary being younger than granite.

"I was in a ska band for six weeks," Gary said, straight-faced. "We were called skA+ which seemed clever at the time. It's not a talent thing. Crowd decides if you're allowed or not. Most of the time you learn your people are mean. Still want to do it?"

"More than the other things," Tom said, which was true.

He went to bed astonished that he'd done something. The bedsit had that brittle quiet of single-occupancy places, soft objects arranged to look like they weren't assigned to one pair of hands. He lay on his back and thought about lights. The kind that make a tunnel out of the world and put you inside it. He had been under those lights once—well, twice. The first time was Year Six Play, a scandal of paper crowns and cellophane stars. He was an angel then, a sacred mistake in wings made of net curtaining, and the light made him feel as if somebody had finally seen the shape of him. The second time was when his mum went. The hospital lights made everything look like a coin you found in a gutter. He stored both experiences in the same cupboard of his brain that he couldn't bear to open or to forget.

He woke before his alarm, because his body didn't trust clocks. He shaved with a razor that had lost interest. He sang to the mirror and believed he improved marginally around the lower notes. He ate toast and put jam on it with discipline. On the way out, he ran his hand along the banister, which, despite appearances, had one loose nail that gave a secret thrill like a hinge with a plan. He told Mr Dray's door, "Good luck today" because he believed in inter-apartment relations like that. He was answered with a cough that could have been agreement or despair.

Back at St. Pilgrim's, he found the noticeboard disorganised in a way that made you want to blow at it and watch the papers reorder themselves like flocking birds. He took the pins out of one corner at a time, sighed each sheet into place, tacked them back with care. It made the day gentler, knowing something in the world had been sorted. He fixed a radiator that had decided to impersonate a glacier. He re-grouted a bit of the Year 3 boys' loos with a patience that would shame saints. He fetched a box of cardboard shapes and elastic bands from the storage cupboard and turned it into a twentieth-century spaceship with a donkey's head. The children saw it at lunchtime and yelped as if he had conjured a dog.

He was wiping glue from his hands with the ease of habit when his phone made that uncertain sound it made when it received a message. It was the sound of a small thing dropping into a bigger thing. Unknown number. He opened it as one opens a fortune cookie, with equal parts hope and amusement. Please call re: South East Song Quest. It had numbers in the message, complete and not smudged at all.

He felt a hot thing move up his spine. A tingle at the base of the skull that people talk about like it's magic. He stepped into the cleaner's cupboard because he wanted walls around him when he rang. The smell of bleach and almond made his eyes water. He dialed and he waited and the line picked up with a recorded voice that told him he was important and then a real voice that sounded like someone with a smile that had been stapled to her face.

"Hello, South East Song Quest. You've reached Marianne."

"Hello, Marianne. I am... I'm Tom. I sent you an email. I mean a friend did. I'm the caretaker. He is. We are the caretaker. Are. Am."

"Lovely," Marianne said, proof that you can say nothing and still sound like you're in charge. "Yes, so, we've looked at your application. We don't normally—well, this is unusual—" She laughed, a professional laugh. "We have a wildcard final slot for a community champion this year. One of our finalists had to pull out. If you could attend the final, next month, we would love to have you. We've had a look at your profile, and it's really touching. 'You fix the world while humming.'"

"Gary," Tom said softly, because there was such a thing as a friend who could choose better words than you could when you needed them.

"Sorry?"

"Yes," he said brightly to cover it. "Yes. Yes. The final."

"We'll sort your song choice nearer the time. You can't do My Way, I'm afraid. Or Hallelujah. Legal reasons mostly. And we might do a small film about you in your day-to-day if that's all right. Nothing intrusive."

"I can do not-My-Way," Tom said, feeling delightful. He thought of the boys by the steps. Perhaps they'd be proud.

"We'll send you a pack. There will be forms. It's not glamorous. But the stage is."

"I know." The words came out like a prayer you'd say in a church you'd wandered into because of weather.

Marianne rattled off details: dates he would forget immediately, times he wrote on his palm with a Bic that read only on the third attempt, what to wear and what not to, where to stand and what not to say to sponsors. He said yes too many times. He hung up and put his head against the door and laughed, a small neat laugh that could turn mean if you took away the air.

He went back to the hall dazed, to find Mrs Penney adjusting a microphone stand. "You look like someone who has swallowed a helium balloon," she said.

"I have... news." He wasn't good at saying big things like they were small things. He was either too loud or too careful.

Mrs Penney put her hands into her pockets, the signal of a woman who is about to weigh. "Is it news I want to know, or a morale hazard?"

"I've been invited to the final of a singing contest. The last—well, the last bit. In Tunbridge Wells. I'll be on... a stage."

"You'll be on a stage," she repeated, her tone revealing nothing. Then she gave him a little smile, the kind she kept for children who'd made something recognisable out of glue. "Well then. We'll put up a notice for you in the staffroom. 'Big Tom. Small Stage.' No. 'Stage Tom, Thin Ice.'"

"Don't be horrid," he said, and then a pity came over her face like a veil and she reached out and patted the back of his hand, once, quick, as if that made a difference to the shape of any of it. She didn't say the thing she could have said, which was either kind or lazy.

Word got around because words fly better than birds. The Year 5 girls wore expressions of sarcasm that had been pinned to their faces by older sisters. A TA called Sandra told him she was "dead proud if it's on the level." Gary sent a text with three thumbs up and a skull, which counted as serious endorsement. Kira wrote on a napkin, which she handed him ceremonially when he came in for his lemonade: You're going to smash it! She drew a microphone that looked like a lollipop. He folded the napkin and put it in his wallet like a prayer card.

He phoned his sister because he didn't want to. Nina lived in Gravesend and could not imagine living anywhere smaller than London or bigger than a lap. She was what people call capable like it's a compliment and an accusation both.

"You what," she said after he had told her. It wasn't a question so much as a scalpel.

"They have a thing for a community champion," he explained, loving how noble that sounded. "For someone who works with—"

"You mop floors, Tom," she said. "I mean. Yes. It's good. It's honest. But don't let them do a thing on you like you're Mother Teresa with a squeegee. People like to laugh. At you, which you know, or at the story. Promise me you don't sign anything without—"

"They're not out to hurt me," he said, hearing the child's turn in his voice. "It's a nice thing. I'm being... included. I haven't been... included. Not like this."

She was quiet long enough for him to know she was choosing between being the sister who cares and the sister who wins. "Okay," she said eventually. "I will come. If you want me. Or I won't, if that makes it easier. Either way, I'm here, which is ridiculous because I am there, but I'm here."

"Come," he said, suddenly, wanting her in a seat if only to have someone to look up at who would remind him he didn't come from nowhere. "Wear something that doesn't rustle."

"You're absurd," she said, and he felt like someone had draped a blanket over a chair and called it a tent.

The days changed their shape. The school stayed itself, stubborn, a river that would not be told what to do by a man with a bucket. But around it, everything in him sharpened. He began to rehearse without permission. He sang in the hall when empty, and in the cleaner's cupboard with the light off, and in the echoing cavity of the gym store where netballs nested. He found a song in his throat that he didn't know he had: something old, almost liturgical, that had a place for a trembling voice. He hummed in the corridor and the children hummed back, unaware of what they were doing: being accomplices.

At the pub, Kira tried to give him a shot of something that tasted like burnt oranges. He sipped and winced and said it was good with an honesty that made her laugh. In the laundrette, Gary made him watch videos of people being ruined by the internet, then videos of people being made by it. They all had the same light in their eyes, which either meant the light had to be there or the light came on when it was pointed at you. He studied their mouths. He practised standing with one foot slightly in front of the other, like a person in a magazine. He bought a shirt that didn't belong to him yet from a shop where young men rolled the sleeves the way people on telly do.

He didn't sleep well. The bedsit magnified the smallest sounds, as small rooms do, so that every mote became a mote with a face. He sat up and drank water and thought of his mother humming. She had had a voice like a kettle just before it whistles. You could hear the promise in it, the potential for something louder. He thought about his dad, who had had a voice like a door closing. He tried to remember the last time someone had clapped for him. He couldn't, so he made a time up. He decided it had happened when he fixed the lift that one winter, and Mrs Penney clapped, because she did sometimes, with a single crisp sound that meant well done and please stop.

What surprised him was the way people came to him with their stories. A boy from Year 6 told him about his mum's midnight shifts because of the electricity. A teacher told him about a man she had wanted to be with and wasn't. The postman told him about singing in a bar in Malaga every August, because his wife made him and then he didn't want to stop. He absorbed all of it. It lent weight to the idea that he was part of something. That he could be embellished with all their could-have-beens.

On a Friday, the school held its assembly for "Music Through the Ages" which was mostly an opportunity for Mrs Penney to play the piano and for the students to move their mouths in a way that could be called singing if the lights were low. Tom watched from the side like a stagehand. At the end, someone—Sandra probably—called him up. "Mr Merriweather will sing us out." It wasn't ordered; it wasn't kindness exactly. It was like being pushed gently into a pool.

He went. The hall was indiscretely bright. The piano waited like furniture. He stood and he put one foot in front of the other like a magazine and he opened his mouth and the sound came. He thought it good. He thought it strong on certain vowels. He thought it wobbled on purpose. The children watched him with that odd attention children have for adults who are being the wrong sort of adult. He finished and there was clapping, thin and combined like the sound of rain on a tin roof. He caught Gary in the doorway because of course he had come and of course he was leaning, and Kira next to him with eyes like a cartoon. He tried not to cry, which would have made everything worse and better.

He received a packet in the post the following Tuesday, which made the day open like a mouth. It had his name on a label he kept and placed under a magnet shaped like a strawberry. Inside there were forms, as Marianne had said, asking about allergies and availability and whether he agreed to be filmed in the vicinity of his workplace and what charity he would dedicate his performance to. He chose the hospice because the hospice was the only place people had said his name with gentleness in their mouths that week in his whole life. He signed where required. He used his best pen, which meant it didn't work on the first try.

The film crew said they'd come on Friday afternoon, to catch him at his work and at his leisure. He spent twenty minutes wondering if he had leisure, decided he did not, decided it could be invented. He told Mrs Penney, who nodded stiffly and ordered the children to be feral somewhere else. He told Kira and she did something to her hair that made it look like an apology. He told Gary, who said he would be available to play himself as the "sarcastic friend with heart of gold" if the budget allowed. He cleaned the corridor twice that morning, because he wanted it to shine in a way that the camera would think was natural.

They arrived with equipment in cases that made him feel as if he had been cast as a destination. Two people: a cameraman who had tattoos peeking like secrets from under his sleeves, and a producer whose ponytail could have been a metronome. They had names, but they said them quickly, as if they were interchangeable. They had a list of shots that had been chosen to make him look competent and humble and, ideally, charming in an entirely non-threatening way. "Can we get you opening a door?" the producer asked as if this were a test.

"I can open a door," he said, with the gravity of someone who could.

They filmed him opening three doors, from different angles. They filmed him sweeping a corridor. They filmed him adjusting a chair. They asked him if he could sing while sweeping and he said yes and then he did, and it felt silly until it felt right, and then it felt silly again. Children wandered into frame and were gently moved by the corralling arms of the producer, who did this without touching anyone, like a magician. They asked him questions, and he answered in sentences that made sense until later when he thought perhaps they had not. "Why do you want this?" "Because it's a wanted thing." "What does music mean to you?" "It's a coat that fits." "What will you do if you win?" "Probably cry. Then mop up."

They filmed him in his bedsit, which made him flinch. He had tidied but there is a way that a room reveals a person even when the person thinks they have closed curtains over their soul. The camera saw everything: the strawberry magnet, the folded napkin with a drawing of a microphone, the post-it with his name on it, the old teapot that had belonged to a woman who hummed. They asked him to sing there too. He did. It was strange how the room absorbed the noise, how the walls listened like friends trying not to smile.

After they left, he sat in the quiet and felt like someone had taken a blueprint of him and folded it back into something else. He tried not to wonder how he would look on a screen. He tried not to imagine the sound of strangers clapping. He went to the window and put his palm flat against the cool glass, because sometimes a person needs to be stopped by something.

He ate beans on toast and forgot to put pepper on it, which his mother would have called a sin even if she hadn't believed in anything. He lay on the bed and stared at the crack in the ceiling he called Norway because of its shape. He tried to pray, but it looked like talking to himself and he laughed instead. The laugh sounded thin. A bus wheezed past. The floorboard above squeaked and was still. He logged into nothing and thought about all the songs he couldn't choose. He practised silence, because he'd been told once that the best singers knew it. He called Nina and hung up before it connected. He picked up the phone again and put it down again and then he slept because he'd exhausted his options.

The film ran on the local news on Wednesday. Gary recorded it in a way that involved an external hard drive and swearing. They gathered at The Oast House to watch it because it turns out there are rituals even for people who don't have rituals. The pub smelled of damp coats and chips and wet wood. Kira wiped down the bar with theatrical thoroughness. When the segment came on, everyone noticed at once, because the atmosphere changed; it became the sort of quiet that isn't quiet at all.

There he was, on the screen, a smaller him inside a bigger him. He watched himself roll a bin, beautiful in its ugliness. He watched himself open a door with the tenderness of a man touching a sleeping baby. He watched himself answer questions and he looked like a person who had been told a joke that he didn't get but decided to laugh at anyway. He heard his own voice and thought it strange that it sounded like that, both thinner and thicker than the one he knew. The children were in it too in a blur, faces left anonymous by the cunning of editing. The piece ended with him on the steps outside, the river behind him doing its best to look like it meant it, and him saying, "We deserve lights sometimes, even if it's just a torch under a chin." The pub clapped because of course it did, and the sound made him want to sit on the floor.

Afterwards, people came up and touched his arm like it was a talisman. A woman said he reminded her of her husband, who could do almost what he could but didn't. A man said he'd vote for him if voting was allowed. Someone bought him a pint of lemonade and then someone else upgraded it to a proper pint that he accepted because refusing made people feel embarrassed about their generosity. Nina texted a picture of her TV with his face on it and wrote: Honestly, you. Then: I'm proud, which he read three times because it didn't look like a word she would write unless she was choosing.

He walked home a local hero, which is to say people decided to see him. A teenager called him Legend which is the word all teenagers keep in their pockets for anyone who looks them in the eye without flinching or selling them something. He took it and tucked it somewhere he would find when he needed it. He climbed the stairs and put his key in the lock and listened to the tiny sound it made. The hinges greeted him like he had taught them to. The carpet smelt like new, which it never did. He sat on the bed and tried not to rehearse winning and losing. He rehearsed instead the moment when he would walk on to the stage and there would be that tunnel of light and he would be in it and he would not be afraid. He was tired beyond the place tiredness comes from. He lay down and the bedsit held him like a carton holds an egg, and he slept—he slept like someone who has a job to do and wants to do it well, even if the job is waking up.

The next morning, everything went wrong in small polite ways. The kettle refused to boil to the required level of anger. His shirt decided to be crumpled in a pattern he had no iron for. The sky might rain, or not. On the way to school, a bus sprayed him with a courteous arc of clean water. "Bless you," he said to the bus, because he could be generous.

At St. Pilgrim's, a pipe burst in the Year 1 cloakroom and wrote its name in damp along the baseboard. He shored it up with a bar towel and a clamp and a prayer and later with a plumber who came in with an attitude and revised it to something workable. Children skated on the wet floor because that is what they do when faced with a hazard. He swore under his breath in a language Nina would have recognised. He held the door for a teacher whose hands overflowed with art. He made a tea that looked right and did nothing and he drank it anyway.

His phone vibrated around midday. Another number. He answered because he had learned to answer now that there were more things that might be news.

"Tom? It's Marianne," she sang, her bright tone dented. "Everything's fine. It's fine. Just—there has been a tiny change. It's nothing. Don't worry."

"I will worry if you say don't," he said. "That's how I am."

"It's about the dinner," she said. "The pre-final dinner next week with the sponsors. It's quite small. Will you be all right? It's at Le Pingouin. There's a menu. We—someone mentioned you might be vegetarian. Are you?"

"Only by accident," he said, and he meant it. "I'll be fine. I'll be brilliant. I'll wear my shirt."

"Good," she said. "All right then. See you Friday for the rehearsal bit. You're doing so well." The last sentence sounded like something she says to children who had made numbers on a sheet happen in a certain order. He wanted to be offended and couldn't quite be.

Le Pingouin was not a place he went to. He had walked past it and felt the chill that comes off posh places like a air-conditioning set to discomfort. He imagined now what he would look like inside it, with his new shirt and the eager way he would speak and the way his hands spoke for him. He practised saying "medium rare" and then corrected to "well-done" because he'd never quite learned to trust red. He imagined linen napkins, and everyone saying each other’s names over and over.

He told Gary, who said, "Don't let them put anything into your drink that glows in the dark. And don't let them make you sing into a cutlery holder. That's a trick."

He told Kira, who said, "People like you or they don't, Tom. Fancy knives don't change that. Don't go in hungry. Wear your heart in your chest, not your sleeve. And for the love of the gods of Kent, don't take a selfie with a prawn."

He promised all the things a man promises when he wants to be trustworthy and has few tools beyond the sincerity of his face. He could feel the days narrowing, a funnel to a point that glinted. He could feel that there would be a moment when he would think a thought he wouldn't be able to change. He had had those before. He tried not to look for them.

That evening, a new poster appeared on the mural wall that said, THIS IS YOUR MOMENT in a font so enthusiastic it was almost rude. He thought of crossing out the word YOUR and writing OUR but he had no pen.

He went home with a bag of shopping that had aspirations. The little Tesco near the river had put the posh pasta on special and he felt fancy choosing the shells that looked like something you could put to your ear. He bought tomatoes and the basil that came in a pot so even the leaves sounded like they've got something to live for. He chose a kilogram of lemons because it seemed like a thing a person who could sing might do for reasons that would be revealed later. He put everything on the counter like offerings.

Mr Dray knocked after nine. He never knocked. He coughed through the open air instead, most days. He stood in the doorway with a face like someone who had looked for something all day and found he ought to have been looking somewhere else.

"You made the telly," he said, as if he were translating from a dialect. "You sounded all right."

"Thank you," Tom said. He stepped aside. "Do you—do you want to come in?"

Mr Dray looked at the threshold like it had rules. "No. No. Just. Don't get silly. They make you silly. Sing into your pillow when you need to. Not for them. For you." He left without a goodbye, which counted as kindness in his language.

Tom closed the door and leaned his head against it because it was becoming a habit. He could feel the world on the other side of the wood. He could feel all the versions of himself he'd been gathering like paperweights. He whispered the names of songs to the crack in the ceiling. He decided which one would show him at his best, which is a different question to which one he loved.

He tried to picture the stage in Tunbridge Wells. He had been to the Assembly Hall once, university girls singing a cappella in dresses that knew what they wanted. He remembered the feel of the seats, a bit too polite. He remembered not knowing where to put his hands. He imagined now hearing his name through the speakers, a small local name carried proudly to the far corners of a very ordinary soundscape. He practised walking onto the stage. He practised not tripping. He practised saying "Thank you" without a bleat.

He slept finally with the window crack-open and the river smuggling in its breath. He dreamed of a corridor that went on so long it had to be a lie, and of a mop that was also a microphone, and of his mother standing in the wings with her hands wrapped in her jumper sleeves, watching him like everything was happening for the right reasons.

Morning came. It does. He was tired. He put on his new shirt for no good reason other than to test it for fits. It fit. He made tea, and the tea was the right colour, which happens sometimes and you should not pretend it isn't a blessing. The day went as days do. He swept and fixed and opened and closed. He thought about the dinner and the stage and the light. He kept thinking of the corridor in his dream. Some doors staying shut, and some opening, and some painted to look like they would.

He found a feather in the cloakroom, grubby at the end, beautiful at the top. He picked it up and tucked it behind his ear and then took it out because he remembered he was seen. He put it in his pocket instead. He did not imagine himself a bird. He imagined himself a man with a feather in his pocket, which is different, and gentler.

He whistled. He forgot he was not supposed to. The corridor looked down at him fondly and with reproach. He accepted both. He moved along the day toward the promise of a small white tablecloth and the first bite of a dinner that would make him think he had been invited to the inside of something. He moved along the day toward an evening in which someone would pour him a glass of wine and, perhaps, a person would say, "So, Tom, tell us about yourself," and he would say, "I repair things," and that would be enough. He moved along the day toward the part of the story he had begun telling himself at night, in the places between waking and whatever that other thing is that isn't dying and isn't peace and isn't even rest, but stands in for them when there is no time left for thinking.

In the corridor by the Year 3 classroom, the sunlight made a rectangle on the floor that looked like a window you could step into. He stepped into it, because he had a second, and in that shaft of gold he raised his arms and he sang one note, long and ridiculous. The lights didn't shake. The walls didn't crack. A child walked by and laughed and then did a cartwheel, uninvited, perfect. He bowed to the child like she was an audience of many, and she bowed back, solemn as a tiny monarch, and then was gone, and the day went on.The week shuffled forward like a deck that refused to be cut clean. He could feel the dinner ahead of him the way you feel weather through a window: something pressing and interesting that didn't have to do with the room you were in until it did. He tried to pick a song the way a person tries to choose a suitcase for a long trip, not too heavy and not too flimsy, something that would arrive intact no matter how it was handled. He tried them on in the hall at St. Pilgrim’s with his mouth for a mirror and the sprung floor judging him gently. Molly Malone made him think too much about his mother and not enough about the notes. A hymn nudged at him and he pushed it away because he didn't want to be mistaken for pious when all he was was faithful. Then in the cleaner's cupboard, where the light always came on with the lag of a thought, he found himself singing something that had been part of the furniture of his head so long he'd forgotten it had a name: The Water Is Wide, the kind of song that makes room for mistakes and means them. He sang it once and then he sang it again quieter and found that the second time the cupboards held their breath for him.

He took himself to the library because he trusted rooms full of paper to tell the truth without flinching. The librarian had a brooch shaped like a lark and a way of stamping dates like she was pinning butterflies. He told her he needed books on folk songs and she led him to a shelf as if to say, Here are other people's mouths you can borrow. He sat at a table scored by pencils that had lived a long time and traced lyrics with his finger like they might smudge. He read old words that had outlasted the hands that had made them and thought that perhaps that was the least he could ask for a night on a stage: to be a conduit. He hummed into the pages, which was ridiculous and made him feel happy, and the lark-brooch lady didn't scold him, which made him love her. He copied out The Water Is Wide in his own handwriting because he had an idea that if he wrote it down he could carry it with more respect. When he reached the line about leaning on a trusty friend, he smiled without meaning to and thought of a laundrette with a man behind a counter who could hack an election if he felt like it and chose instead to fix people's spin cycles.

He told Gary his choice and Gary approved with a face that didn't let on that it approved, which is the only way Gary ever approved of anything. "It's old enough not to sue you and strong enough to keep you upright," he said, turning the pronouns in a way that made Tom feel steadied. "Sing it like you aren't trying to impress anyone you'll never meet. And for the love of everything, do not attempt a key change unless you are offered a knighthood midway." Kira listened as if she were learning the shape of a storm and said she would take a long break and stand in the back during the final so he could pretend the dark was full of people who wanted what he wanted. "Also," she added, wiping a glass that had no smudge, "if Marianne asks you to do your song as a snippet at the dinner, you tell her you will give them a hum and a smile and they can pay for the full show later. No freebies for the penguins."

On Thursday, he went to the hospice because he had written their name on a form and it seemed sensible to show his face to the place he had given his heart. The reception smelled like clean laundry and dignity. A nurse with a tattoo of a forget-me-not on her wrist recognised him from the news and laughed the kind of laugh people do when the world has done something benign and inexplicable. She walked him along a corridor that had soft pictures of trees where there would be windows if money and architecture were kinder. He didn't go into any rooms because he had resolved not to make anyone's last days into a thing that gave him something, but he sang a verse under his breath to the carpet anyway. At the end of the corridor a woman in a green dressing gown sat with her feet in slippers that looked like boats. "Oh," she said, as if she had found a coin. "You are that caretaker. Sing the river one." He did a fragment, nothing that would break the air, and her eyes shone in a way that could have been pain or joy or merely eyes doing their job in a room where something sort-of nice had happened. The nurse squeezed his elbow, which is not a place people often squeeze, and as he left he thought of Nina saying, Don't let them use you, and of how complicated the word them always is.

Friday's rehearsal at the Assembly Hall made him feel like an ant in a jewellery box. He signed his name on a sheet next to other names that had better angles than his did. He watched a girl in a red coat flocked with tiny moths warm up by turning her mouth into a trumpet and admired the efficiency of it. A boy with hair that looked rehearsed had a guitar in a case that could have survived a crash, and an older man with a waistcoat you could draw maps on stood with his hands in pockets like the pockets might talk if he let them. Marianne materialised with her ponytail and her clipboard and the kind of smile you put on when you're about to direct traffic on a motorway no one agreed to stand on. She touched his arm like it was a button that would reassure him and pointed him towards a stagehand called Shaz who smelled faintly of fresh sawdust and wore a radio like a second ear. "Mic check, love," Shaz said, handing him a microphone with tape around it that announced the number 3 as if it were auspicious.

The stage was a country all of its own. The floor was black and sticky with history and the lights were the kind that don't decide whether to flatter or expose you until it's too late. A man in the back who answered to FOH and Matt in equal measure asked him to say his name and address like a person on a complaint call. He said them and heard his voice come back at him smug and bigger than it had ever been. He thought of what his mother would have said: Stand up straight or you'll tell them you don't mean it. Shaz told him, "Don't eat the mic, pet. Let it hear you like you trust it. Sing past it, not into it." He tried, and the first note snuck out as if worried it was in the wrong place, and then the second drew itself up and the third did something good around the edges. He put one foot in front of the other like the magazine had taught him and tried not to watch himself in his head as he did it.

In the corner, Marianne watched with two other people who were probably important, if only because they looked like they were rehearsing being unimpressed in case the real thing turned up. She smiled at his chorus with her teeth and at his verse with her eyes and made a note when he tangled his tongue at a line that had never tangled before. "It's the lights," Shaz said later, friendly and fierce in the same sentence. "They don't just light you. They weigh you. Don't let them. Park your nerves in the wings with the push-brooms. We'll guard them. Go on then, once more for me and imagine you're singing to a wall you love."

He did and the wall obliged him by becoming the river in his head and the corridor at school and his mother's face at two in the morning when the kettle hasn't quite told you yet what it intends. When he finished, Matt in the back nodded, which might have been a trick of the light but felt like a thing a person could put in a pocket. He thanked the air, because there was no one else to thank without looking like a man who needed a hug. The other contestants clapped like people who understood exactly where they were and how much it took to get there, which was to say politely and without the dangerous generosity that can scupper a person who isn't expecting it.

After rehearsal, Marianne handed him a lanyard with his face on it in glossy and text that made him look called. "Le Pingouin on Tuesday," she said, the French drifting in her mouth like a decorative fish. "Seven for seven-thirty. Dress smart. Smart-smart, not just smart." He didn't ask her to define it because he was learning that sometimes the trick is to guess and let people tell you how well you guessed afterwards. She mentioned sponsors like a weather forecast: a local bank that had renamed itself after a kind of tree, a chain of garden centres with confusing ambitions, a telecoms firm that turned out to be a man. "They're lovely," she said. "They all think music saved them and want to return the favour at scale."

Saturday he wanted to be useful, so he over-shined the hall floor until it stared back at him offended. He oiled the hinges of the cupboard that refused to let the netballs breathe. He fixed a high window with a pole and a patience that would have chastened monks. Children weren't there and the building made its building noises unselfconsciously; the sighs and ticks and the gurgle in the radiators like someone telling a joke with too much preamble. He sang into the emptiness and it took the sound and laid it down somewhere he couldn't see. He told himself not to think of dinner and failed by lunchtime. He took his new shirt out of its bag and ironed it as if he were flattening a landscape. He borrowed a jacket from the charity shop with lavender and bright wool and it fitted in the way some things fit when you pretend not to care if they don't.

He called Nina and it rang unusually long, then her voice turned up brisk and textured like toast. He told her when and where and she told him to send a drop pin, which he couldn't, so he promised to text the name and a description of the door. "Don't let anyone take you outside to show you a car," she said, as if this were the kind of place where men in coats would attempt to sell him timeshares in shame. "Sit near someone you can talk about the weather with if it goes wrong. Weather saves conversations. And if they make you speak, keep it under thirty seconds and say a joke that doesn't ask anyone to laugh. Then everyone will."

On Tuesday, Le Pingouin presented itself like a bird that had heard rumours about swans. The windows were glossy and the door had a handle that made your hand feel judged. Inside, everything was flatteringly lit and the tables wore white like a promise. Tom stood in the entrance and tried not to look like he was thinking of carpet stains. Marianne appeared in a dress that would have been a different person if it had a choice and steered him into a room where noise made little fountains in corners. "Tom," she said brightly to a cluster of people who were both one person and many, "this is Tom Merriweather, our Community Champion wildcard. Tom, these are our partners." They said their names and their roles and their companies, and he nodded at the appropriate times and produced his handshake like a good coat.

The other finalists were arranged like a set of possibilities. Red-coat trumpet-mouth was called Lana and had a laugh she kept under the table where she could kick it if necessary. The boy with the guitar was Dev and he did something in IT that he treated like a hobby when he talked about singing, which made Tom like him more. The waistcoat man was Mr Crozier and he showed his teeth when he smiled as if he were paying tax on the gesture. There was Aisha, seventeen and exacting and accompanied by parents who were trying hard not to look as if they had smuggled their hearts in under their jackets. There were two more: a woman named Paula who ran a choir in Sittingbourne and had very careful hair, and an ex-club singer everyone called Les because that was his name and also because it was the right size.

They ate things that tasted like concepts before they tasted like food. Tom took small sips of wine and then larger sips of water and looked at the menu as if it had opinions about him. He found the cheapest thing and couldn't order it without confessing, so he picked a chicken dish with a name that had gone to university. Conversation eddied and broke against him and rejoined elsewhere. Someone asked him what time he started work and he said six and they said, "Oh, your day is our nightmare," and he laughed because it was true and not. A woman from the bank asked him if he believed music had the power to heal communities, and he said it had the power to make them stand still for a bit and that was a start, and she wrote that down as if he had said something clever, which he supposed he had by accident.

Halfway through the main course, a man with a tie that resembled a quiet argument stood and tapped a spoon on a glass. The sound made Tom want to reach for a Jacob's cracker. "Ladies and gentlemen," the man said, and the room did what rooms do to that phrase. "What an honour to support such talent. We thought, perhaps, we might persuade one of our fabulous finalists to give us a little foretaste of Friday? Just a bar or two." He smiled at the group in a way that made them all feel hospitable. Tom looked at Marianne, whose smile did something not entirely kind to her face and then recovered. Dev was looking studiously at a bread roll as if it had embarrassed him. Lana shook her head once in a small circle that said not tonight in a dialect only performers use. Les was halfway to standing because Les was born standing in rooms like this and sat back down because someone put a hand on his sleeve.

Tom felt people glance at him in that way the English have when they want someone else to be brave so they can applaud quietly without admitting to having wanted anything. He thought of Kira's voice in his head telling him no freebies for the penguins and of Shaz saying park your nerves in the wings. He put his napkin down slowly to give himself time not to be heroic. "I could hum," he said, and the table laughed as if he had told a joke, which perhaps he had. "Or," he added, more steady now that he had a sentence sitting in front of him, "I could say that you'll hear us all properly when we're meant to be heard. I think I'll keep mine for the stage. Or the corridor. I'm very good in corridors." There was a ripple that might have been disappointment and might have been respect, and the tie-man nodded like a person who had been refused kindly and knew not to push it.

He went outside anyway between pudding and speeches because he needed air and also needed the feeling of being in a place he recognised. The alley beside the restaurant smelled of lemons that had been made to suffer and of the back of the world. A kitchen porter in a paper hat stood smoking a cigarette as if it owed him money. "All right?" the porter said, as if they were both in a queue for something that might change them. "I saw you on the telly. My nan fancies you." Tom considered the compliment, decided to enjoy it, and laughed. He told the porter he was going to sing a river and the porter said, "Make it a clean one then. I'm sick of dirty water," and dropped his cigarette into a tin of sand like a ceremony. Tom hummed two bars and the alley felt better and then he went in before anyone could decide he'd been gone too long.

The speeches were as speeches tend to be: time converted into syllables. People said words like platform and journey and passion as if they were buying train tickets. Tom clapped whenever eyes turned to him. He drank his coffee as small as possible because he had seen men make mistakes on the third coffee and didn't want to join them. At the end, Marianne squeezed his shoulder with her hand shaped like a metronome and said, "You handled that beautifully," and he could hear the relief in it like a draught. "We don't actually want it, you know, the song in the dining room. We only want to say we asked."

He walked back to the station because the night deserved someone to witness it on foot. The windows of the shops were full of things pretending to be asleep. He paused at the old cinema even though it was out of his way and read the names on the marquee, which were not names he knew but did the job anyway. A fox loped across the road like a man late for a meeting he didn't want to attend. He felt, for a brief ridiculous second, that everything had arranged itself carefully so that he could be in this exact spot to feel exactly what he felt, which was the kind of thought that if you pick at it becomes arrogance or a poem.

Wednesday morning he found a note under the door at St. Pilgrim's written in pencil on lined paper: Dear Mr Merriweather, will you sing us out on Friday before your big sing? Love, Year 3. Someone had drawn a microphone that might have been a lollipop and a star with more points than was strictly necessary. He showed it to Mrs Penney who made a face like one does when tasting soup that was better than expected. "Ten minutes at the end," she said. "No sob story. We'll do that at the fete when the summer fails us. We'll have the children hum with you, on the chorus, so you don't get lonely." He put the note in his wallet next to Kira's napkin and the strawberry magnet pressed it all flat on his fridge when he got home, because that was how talismans liked to be kept: close together, being quietly useful.

Gary kept him from the internet as if he were warding off a cold. "They've started to discuss you," he said at the laundrette, scrolling with his thumb as if politely rubbing a stain. "You are 'authentic' and 'one of those kooky ones' and someone has written that you're fake and cynical and there to tick a box. That's three out of four internet food groups. Do not read it. I'm not even reading it. I'm reading it for you and telling you not to read it." Tom nodded and looked instead at the washing machines going around in their little universes and felt grateful to live in a time when something so ordinary looked like a miracle.

Thursday night he paced his bedsit the way a man paces who is not allowed to run away and does not want to. He pressed his hand to the wall where Mr Dray's cough came from when it came, and it didn't, and he thought about knocking and didn't, and then he did knock and Mr Dray opened the door as if he'd been standing just behind it waiting for something to turn. "Sing into your pillow?" Mr Dray said without preamble, and when Tom shook his head he said, "Good. Save it. They'll give you light. Take what you need and leave before the light changes its mind." It was more words than Tom had ever heard from him in one breath and it felt like a benediction delivered by a man who had resigned from the priesthood in 1979 and still knew the motions.

He barely slept and when he did he found himself in the corridor again, the one that had continued beyond itself for the length of a dream, doors numbered in a logic that could not have stood up under cross-examination. He walked past BRAVERY and HUMOUR and REGRET and STOP SINGING, which had been stuck on with playful cruelty. He tried the handle marked WATER and it opened onto a room that was all windows and somewhere there was his mother humming, not to him this time but to herself as if she liked the company. He woke with his mouth open and a note in it he had to swallow.

Friday at St. Pilgrim's had the feel of a day that had remembered itself. The children were noisy without malice. A glue stick went missing and turned up in the place you keep glue sticks when you want to be found. He made a last round that wasn't last and corrected a wobbly display of planets so that Saturn didn't look like a hat. At two-fifty, he stood in the hall and the school collected itself like a flock that had decided to be one thing for five minutes. He told them that songs were bridges you could put down between two places that didn't agree about the river and that if they wanted they could stand on it and look, and they laughed because he sounded like a teacher and he wasn't. He sang The Water Is Wide and asked them to hum the chorus and the hum came, a woolly blanket of sound that covered the floor and the walls and the time between the bell and whatever came after.

When he walked off the stage-that-was-a-stage-and-also-a-hall, he didn't trip. His legs felt as if he had gone somewhere far and returned with nothing you could show and everything you could use. The day tightened behind him like a knot that holds. He folded the lanyard he had been told not to fold and put it in his pocket anyway. He put the feather from the cloakroom into his wallet next to the napkin and the note and the form that had named his charity. He checked his tool bag because it calmed him. He told the door on the way out, "Wish me a light that doesn't lie," and the door swung as if to say, You'll have what you have, and that will be enough.

He met Nina at the bus stop because good sisters arrive at bus stops like small miracles. She hugged him in that older-sister way that is half scolding, half armour. She had brought a bottle of water and a packet of mints and a look that said she could fight a dragon with a biro. "Don't be late," she said, and he said, "I won't," and she said, "Don't be early either," and he laughed because she had, with that one sentence, explained everything about him that needed explaining. They walked to the Assembly Hall without saying anything invented. He could feel the tilt of the earth under his shoes and believed for the first time that he might not fall off. Inside, the lights waited and the seats waited and somewhere in the wings Shaz was waiting with a radio and Matt with a nod, and behind his heart the part of him that had always wanted a small merciless stage had stopped hiding. He stood in the corridor that led to the wings and thought of the rectangle of sunlight by Year 3 and of the cartwheel and of the bow and this time when he raised his arms he didn't sing. He breathed, and the breath was the size of a life.Backstage smelled of paint that had not fully decided to be dry and of metal scaffolds turning light into geometry. Tom stood with his back to a wall that had met more performances than any critic and breathed as if the air had to be persuaded. Nina was beside him with her handbag like a shield and a calm that was ninety percent act, ten percent training. She spoke softly because the space asked for it, the way churches do, and reminded him of things he already knew: that his feet belonged under him, that his mouth could find the shapes it needed, that the worst thing that would happen would be that he would sing and then he would stop. Shaz buzzed past like a friendly wasp, eyes everywhere, radio chattering. She checked his mic pack and smoothed the cable on his shirt as if it were a ribbon on a present she intended to give the room, then told him again not to eat the mic and to sing past it, not into it. He nodded too many times and she gave him a face which translated as, one nod is enough, sweetheart, save the others for later.

The host strode on in a blue suit that had been chosen by a person who hated blue and the audience responded with that particular British enthusiasm that manages to be loud and self-conscious at the same time. Tom couldn't see much of them yet, just a hint of heads beyond the wings and the curve of the balcony like the lip of a cup. He listened to the patter that warmed them up, the jokes about Tunbridge Wells and parking and how this was the night dreams were made and politely declined, and he felt a wave of affection for people who showed up to be part of something even when they couldn't name what it was. Marianne glided in, clipboard held like a hymn book, and put a hand on his upper arm to steady him or herself. She gave him the order—the first half would belong to three, then an interval and a raffle and a photo op where he would have to stand near a banner that pretended to be a real thing. He was fourth, she said, just after Dev and before Mr Crozier, which felt like standing between a boy at the beginning of a climb and a man who had already decided the view wasn't as good as advertised.

From the wings he watched Lana become a mouth made for trumpets and sorrow and light. She sang something he didn't know but recognised the shape of, and the audience made a sound that wasn't clapping, not yet, but was the sound you make when your attention has been captured. She left the stage with her shoulders relaxed by two degrees and didn't look at anyone because she didn't want to let the look turn into anything else. Dev went next and made the guitar behave as if it had applied for the role of spine and been hired. He had the decency to look terrified between verses and charmed during them, which made the audience believe him. Tom clapped in the dark and shook his hands loose the way Shaz had shown him, fingers tingling, wrists warm, and he thought of the hall at school and the rectangular sunlight, which was a much smaller light but had the same merciless kindness.

When the stage manager held up three fingers and then two and then one, he stepped forward like a man walking onto a ferry. He hadn't expected the floor to sound like that under his shoes; it sounded like it knew the weight of him and it wasn't offended. The mic stand was at his height already because Shaz was a witch for measurements, and the stage lights did their best to turn him into a person who was both only himself and not singular at all. He looked out and saw not faces but the suggestion of faces, the way you know a flock is birds without counting. He thought of the corridor at St. Pilgrim's and of Mrs Penney’s hybrid smile and of Gary's thumbs-up with a skull, which was how some men say prayer. He breathed again as if it mattered and said his name because the host had asked him to and added, against his own preparations, "I fix things," which was not a sob story and not nothing and made two women in row E look at each other with that pleased surprise people keep for a phrase that tucks under the rib.

The first note came from far back in him, somewhere near where the winter coats live, and arrived at his mouth intact. He had started gentler in the rehearsals, but the room asked for a thread drawn firmly and so he drew it. The Water Is Wide moved through him as if it had found a riverbed where it had not expected one and decided to be hospitable. He didn't look at the judges with their pens and their medals and their eyes that had seen everything. He looked at a point just beyond the front row where the darkness holds, and then at the corner where a piece of set met its partner and made a right angle that had never hurt anyone, and then at the space above his head where the dust danced like arguments forgiven. He kept his hands mostly still because Shaz had said stillness terrifies rooms in the right way, and because he wanted to see if his mouth was enough.

In the second verse he heard a cough as delicate as a teaspoon against a saucer and refused to let it be important. He leaned into the lines that knew him and allowed the ones that didn't to borrow his shape for the evening. In the chorus he didn't ask anyone for anything with words, but his voice angled the suggestion at the darkness and a handful of people accepted it without knowing they had. The hum arrived like a mistake everyone agreed to keep, and then grew because it had been welcomed, and then settled into a level that made him feel, for the first time that night, like he was exactly the right size. He didn't smile because smiling would have broken the glass of it, but the corners of his mouth did a thing they hadn't done in months, and Nina in the stalls started to breathe like a person who had been holding it too long.

He didn't attempt the showy fall-off at the end because he had promised Gary he wouldn't, and because he knew in some older part of himself that landing clean is more honest than attempting air and missing. The last word left him and hung for a second that was three seconds long and then the room returned to itself and clapped, which is what rooms do when they have been given something they hadn't ordered and found they liked. It wasn't a roar, because Kent is careful, but it was layered and warm and it grew when a man in the balcony decided to start it again, as if he'd dropped it and wanted a clean take. He bowed the way Shaz had shown him, small and sincere, and the light did not punish him for it.

The host came back on with a smile that had been ironed and said words that meant competent and surprising without saying them. The judges spoke their portion as if they were putting a dressing on something that had lived long enough without one. The radio man, who had a blazer that had known better evenings, said he had found the performance "authentic," which is a word that can be friend or enemy, then added that he liked that Tom hadn't been tempted into tricks. The theatre director, a woman with a fringe like a guillotine, talked about the architecture of the song and the way he understood space, which made him want to look under the stage to see which beams she meant. The former pop star, who wore memory like perfume, said his pitch had wobbled at the top of the second verse but that if all wobbles were like that then childbirth would be easier, which earned him a laugh he didn't quite deserve but took anyway. Someone asked him about the hospice and he said one clean sentence and stopped, because he had promised Nina and also because grief blunts a room faster than it sharpens it.

Back in the wings the air felt like the inside of his mouth after mint. He could hear the audience in the corridor of sound they made between acts and it no longer frightened him. Dev appeared and clapped his shoulder with the kind of hope men his age only allow themselves in the presence of guitars, and said something about the run into the third chorus that Tom would not remember properly later. Lana hugged him fiercely and quickly, all cheekbone and salt, and mused that his vowels were very Kent, which she meant as an astonishment. Mr Crozier nodded like a vicar seeing a good harvest and told him to never, under any circumstances, accept a cruise contract without reading the bit about hurricanes. He laughed and found himself wanting to tell his mother everything that had just occurred, which was ridiculous and correct.

Mr Crozier went on with a song that had a hundred nights in it and three marriages, and Paula followed with something choral and tidy that unfolded like a map, and Aisha sang like a blade being sharpened and the room remembered how young it isn't. The ex-club singer did the thing men like him do, which is to remind you that a room can be made to stand up even if it doesn't feel like it, and the audience stood for him because he ordered them to and they wanted to. Tom watched it all with the eyes of a man who had been allowed to put his spoon into the bowl and found the soup was shared. He did not compare, because comparing would be to look away from what had happened to him and make it smaller.

Interval came with plastic cups and raffle tickets and a person shouting numbers into a semi-receptive din. Kira and Gary found him in a swipe of corridor where light and dark negotiated and told him what they were allowed to tell him without letting their faces break into the faces they wanted to make. Kira said he had made the room hush like she had seen only twice, once when a brawl had nearly started and once when a footballer had come in after a loss and everyone remembered they were people. Gary said he had not embarrassed himself and then rolled his eyes at himself and added that he had, in fact, more than achieved the brief, which was his way of kissing a man on the forehead without having to be present at the scene. Nina handed him water and a mint and pressed his hand harder than was strictly necessary, and in her eyes he saw the version of him that could go home now and be content even if no one said his name again from the stage.

They called them all back for a group bow because someone had decided there was time for it. The host spoke about votes, though the judging was mostly already judged, and about journeys, and about the way the region had talent like a hedgerow has sparrows if you'd only pay attention. Tom stood on his mark, which Shaz had made with tape like a small secret, and pretended to have learned how to share space. He held his lanyard in one hand because he liked the weight of his face on plastic and because it grounded him as well as any saint's bone. He looked out and this time he saw a few faces; people do that once the lights settle and the audience forgets to be one organism. He saw someone from the bakery and a kid from Year 6 with a father who looked surprised to be sitting and Mrs Penney in the aisle looking like a woman who approves of nothing and allows everything.

When the time came to announce things, the room did that paradoxical thing and tightened while pretending to relax. Marianne stood in the wings counting on her fingers like a person at a bus stop to whom time had become a fruit. The judges murmured together with faces like knotty wood, and the host made an applause line where there didn't need to be one and everyone clapped anyway because it filled a dangerous second. Third place went to Dev, and he grinned with his eyes closed as if he were listening to a song no one else could hear. Second went to Lana, and she shook her head as if to dislodge a year and then bowed so beautifully that Tom wanted to take lessons in humility from her elbows. The first went to Aisha, because the world is occasionally tidy in its judgements, and her parents turned into statues that had to check their joints before they could sit. The roar for her came from teenagers who had arranged themselves in a block like a choir that knows a chant and from grandmothers who recognised what it had been like to have a twelve-note name at seventeen and carry it.

After the big three, the sponsors did their bit in a line of photos with handshakes and oversized cheques that looked as if they had been ironed. There was a pause long enough for people to check their phones and then the ex-pop star leaned into the mic and mentioned, almost casually, that there was a special commendation for "contribution to community," which is the kind of phrase that can go either way. He said Tom's name like he had been practising, and the applause happened in that gentle wave again and didn't die too soon, which is the courtesy applause dreams of. They invited him forward and he did his walking and shook the hand of a man who was more telecoms than flesh and held a plaque that would look like a certificate in dim light and a car park voucher in bright. The hospice got a cheque that made a nurse cry somewhere because that's what small cheques do; they arrive in a place that knows how to use small things properly. Tom said thank you and nothing else, because he could feel the hole in the floor that opens for men who think they have more to say than they do and he did not intend to fall into it tonight.

After the photos and the thanks and the bit where everyone pretended food was imminent and then found it wasn't, they were released into a lobby that had opinions about carpet. People came up in drifts and told Tom that their cousin or their dog or their late grandfather would have loved that song, which is how humans measure proximity to the holy. A man with a face like an endangered bird said he didn't know the song but felt like he had and that this was a compliment; Tom accepted it as such and watched the man float away, lighter for having said words to a stranger. A local councillor with a tie that meant business told him that the council cared deeply about arts in the community and that perhaps there could be a mural with his face on it, and he laughed until she realised he was laughing and laughed too as if it had been a joke she had told.

In the corner by a stand of palms that had seen too much, Marianne leaned against a pillar briefly and closed her eyes. When she opened them, she saw Tom looking and gave him a small shrug that in her language equalled confession and relief. She told him quietly that they had worried about the wildcard, that visions of cynical tweets had haunted her, that she had imagined men in newspaper offices making tidy cruelty out of his laces and his face. He said he was glad he had taken that worry from her even if only for a night, and she laughed in shock and then hugged him because people hug men who make their jobs briefly resemble the thing they thought they'd wanted when they were twenty-four and earnest.

When the lobby began to empty and the buzz faded to scraps that would be swept up with programmes, he took his plaque and his lanyard and his small important envelope and found a quiet bit of stair that had been painted grey because grey forgives. Nina sat beside him with her shoes in her hand and her chin tilted up like a person letting rain meet it. She told him he had done it, which was both true and unimportant now that it was done, and he told her she had been there, which was both obvious and vital. They didn't talk about Mum and they didn't talk about Dad because their names were in the air anyway eating up oxygen, and after a while they talked about the bus because there had to be something fixed and human to end on.

The night outside had the particular emptiness that follows crowds. He walked down the hill from the Assembly Hall holding the plaque a little away from his body because he didn't want to accidentally absorb any authority from it that wasn't earned. Gary and Kira peeled off toward the pub with promises of chips and a stern look that said there would be no singing tonight, only salt and vinegar and other ancient cures. Nina headed for her train with the kind of wave you give when you intend to see someone again on purpose, and he turned toward the river because all roads in his head led there now when they could.

He stood on the bridge as he had stood many times and let the water remind him that you can only step into it as yourself, not as the idea of yourself other people like to hold up like a lantern. The lights on the other side had done what lights do and softened the edges of everything, even the ugly bits, even the bits that had been designed by committees that didn't understand corners. He thought about the hum in the chorus and how it had needed no invitation beyond a steady line and a space to settle. He thought about the corridor at school and the girl doing a cartwheel and how some movements are involuntary and perfect when you are nine and almost impossible later when your bones learn about revenge.

He went home the long way because winners and losers alike should have to take the long way after any kind of battle. Finnerty's carpets had been locked properly by someone else for once and the stairs felt like they were more interested in holding him than tripping him. In the bedsit he put the plaque on the table next to the strawberry magnet and the napkin and the feather and the folded lanyard, and it looked ridiculous there, as if the table had put on a hat and regretted it. He boiled water twice because kettles are dramatic after big nights and made tea that was almost right. He sat on the bed and let the quiet introduce itself, which it did, politely and a little smug.

Sleep was slow to come because his body had decided to turn the night over and examine it for defects. As he lay there, he listened for Mr Dray and heard only the kind of silence that knows what it is doing. He put the palm of his hand against the wall the way you do with animals you want to make friends with and thought, very clearly, that he had placed himself under lights and been seen and had not been burned. He allowed himself a small silly thought that the door at St. Pilgrim's would swing a little easier for him on Monday out of respect, and then he told himself not to anthropomorphise wood and he laughed quietly and it sounded like it belonged to him.

In the morning, the day resembled other days more than one expects after a night that has dressed itself up. The toast was toast and not a symbol. The tea did its work without grandstanding.
