He took the plaque down to the carpet shop because Finnerty liked to display local successes next to the Axminster with pride, and Finnerty made a show of giving him a place near the till as if the plaque were a relative stopping by. He walked to St. Pilgrim's with his key ring in his palm and the key ring felt the same weight as ever and he did not resent it. The building flexed its muscles and yawned in pipes and gullies and allowed him in, and he told the doors good morning and meant it in a way he had not known he was capable of.

Children are excellent barometers of change; they decide which weather to believe in within seconds and rarely revise. In the Year 3 corridor, a boy with a cliff for a forehead asked him if he'd met anyone famous and Tom told him he had met himself, which made the boy pull a face as if presented with broccoli. In the hall, a Year 5 girl performed a sarcastic curtsy as she passed him and then turned it into a real one because she had misjudged the day and wanted to adjust. Sandra held his elbow and told him she'd recorded it and watched it twice and cried on the second time because the first was reconnaissance. Mrs Penney looked at him with her shoes pointing in a different direction, which is how she told him she was pleased and needed to be on time for Year 2's phonics regardless.

He fixed a locker that had learned to stutter and enjoyed the exactness of bolts. He uncoiled the hose and told it that it had never looked more serpentine and it allowed itself to be amused. The mop watched him from the corner with a level of respect it had previously reserved for visitors from the council. At lunch, he went to The Oast House and Kira tried to make him eat something with an egg on top and he declined and then accepted because she knew when he was being noble for no audience. Gary arrived late with eyes that had slept and printed a photo of him under the lights from a place on the internet where kindness had happened without supervision and sat it on the table like a small, harmless god.

In the days that followed, the world did not call him to bigger stages, which was a comfort if he was honest and a disappointment if he was being a cliché. There were a few emails that Marianne forwarded, some from people who wanted him to sing at fundraisers and one from a man who wanted to sell him slippers that corrected posture. He said yes to the first kind with the hospitality he had been shown and no to the second with the brevity the internet requires. He went to the hospice on a Thursday with the cheque and the nurse with the forget-me-not on her wrist grinned like a girl at a fair and let him sing in the corridor two full verses this time because a woman in Room 4 had asked and because rules are made by people who have never had to measure hours like that.

Something in him had been rearranged, but it wasn't a furniture you could point at. It was more like someone had moved a plug to a different wall and he could charge parts of himself he hadn't been able to before. He found himself humming when he fixed things and not worrying if anyone heard unless they were taking a test. He found that some of the children hummed back when they were supposed to be fetching lunchboxes, and he pretended to scold them and didn't really. He found that when he walked past the mural that currently said THIS IS YOUR MOMENT he didn't instinctively reach for a pen to edit it. He thought of adding and tomorrow too, but he decided the wall had earned a day off from commentary.

Nina phoned on a Sunday and told him that their Auntie Kel had seen him via a nephew's Facebook and had thoughts about trousers. He listened and agreed to disagree about the hems because there is a kind of argument that keeps people in the right relation to each other if conducted with enough tea. She asked him, at the end, quiet in her mouth, whether he was all right with having had a night and then returning to days, and he thought about lying and didn't. He told her it had been like standing under a waterfall and then walking to the corner shop, that both activities had turned out to be more related than he would have guessed. She told him he had always been a poet even when he was trying to be a cupboard and laughed at herself with affection.

On a damp Tuesday, he found a slip of paper in his pigeonhole at school with a note in a child's hand declaring that he should start a singing club because otherwise how would anyone know how. He held it and thought of rooms he could make slowly and carefully; rooms where humming was the weave and glue was permitted and posters were hand-drawn and the door would always be slightly ajar. He took the paper to Mrs Penney as if he were offering a foundling and she pursed her lips as if tasting soup again and said they'd make a slot on Wednesdays if he promised not to cause a riot. He promised to cause only manageable revolutions and she nodded like a queen being generous after a nap.

The first club met in the gym store because there was a plug and enough echo to flatter small braveries. Six children arrived and then two more and then Aisha's younger brother turned up with a recorder which he brandished like a weapon and was reassured was welcome. They sang a bit and talked a lot and he discovered that the thing he enjoyed more than singing for people might be convincing people that they can do it too, that their voices are not accidents but instruments with dust you can blow off. He taught them The Water Is Wide in a key that didn't frighten anyone and when they hummed the chorus he closed his eyes for a second and thought of the Assembly Hall and of how space can be persuaded to listen if you speak to it kindly.

When he walked home that evening there was a thin light that can't be relied upon but makes promises anyway. Finnerty's sign clicked on with hope and the bedsit smelled like whatever Mr Dray had cooked—something with onions and something else that felt proprietary—and he stood in the doorway and felt, with what he realised was surprise, that his life fitted him. It was not a tailored thing. It didn't sit on the shoulders as if a man in a tape measure had sighed over it; it was a good charity-shop jacket that he had warmed into shape and that now felt like it would resist rain longer than it had a right to. He put the kettle on and it hissed its approval and he sang half a verse to the teapot because he could and because the room had earned a lullaby without an audience. The song floated into the corners and settled with the dust and with what had always been there, and if the mops stiffened a little less and the hinges minded their manners, well, that was only fair.It wasn't a new beginning exactly, but the days grew edges he could feel with his fingers. If he had been the sort of man to number things he'd have said it was chapter six, though he didn't write in chapters and he certainly did not keep an index. What he noticed instead was that the morning light came into his bedsit with a new habit of tapping at the glass, and that the kettle, when it boiled, sounded less like a reprimand and more like encouragement. He went to St. Pilgrim's with his ring of keys spinning a little faster than they had, like small moons taking their cue from a parent planet that had remembered to pull. The building greeted him with its usual creaks and he greeted it with his usual murmurs, but the conversation had shifted by a degree; it was as if the walls had decided to take him at his word.

The singing club began with six children and accrued two, then shed one to football and gained one from netball and ended up with nine, which felt like a number books liked. He ran it in the gym store because the echo there was friendly and the plug was in a place that didn't argue with extension leads. They began with humming because humming was democratic, then graduated to a round that made the space stack itself into a new shape. There was a boy called Keir who wanted to turn everything into beatboxing and a girl called Amara who sang so quietly that the sound seemed to draw itself with a pencil, and an older sister who arrived to collect a younger one and pretended not to care until she failed at pretending and stayed. Tom stood and moved his hands the way he'd seen conductors do on telly and discovered that the trick wasn't to command but to invite, and that if you left a gap people filled it with courage.

"What's the point of a singing club?" a Year 4 boy asked bluntly on the second week, poking at the concept like it might be undercooked. "We're not a choir. We don't even have uniforms."

"The point is to breathe together in a room," Tom said, pleased to hear himself say it and slightly appalled at the poetry of it. "And to make something that didn't exist before the bell went. Also, biscuits on the last Thursday." The last sentence made immediate sense. He had learned that sugar bridged any gap that metaphysics couldn't.

When he wasn't coaxing voices out of children he was building a universe out of cardboard because Goldilocks in Space had a deadline and Year 2 had expectations that were at once vague and adamant. The donkey-ship had grown a nose cone and a tail that looked like ambition. He had begged elastic bands from the office and bought silver paint with his own money after someone in the PTA declared that glitter was microplastic and therefore immoral. He hummed while he glued because it made the glue less sulky. He scraped a line of dried PVA off the tabletop with his thumbnail and thought about how all technologies end up being about holding and letting go in the right doses.

At The Oast House, Kira put a chalkboard up near the till that read, in an uncharacteristically neat hand, Singing Club Cake Sale, Friday 3:30, Please Be Nice. She claimed she would make brownies that could settle disputes between kingdoms and dared Tom to sing Mozart with his mouth full. Gary, who had rolled his eyes at the idea of helping in public and then turned up with a float tin and a cheap card reader that required coaxing, declared every fourth slice to be on the house if the purchaser could name a folk song that hadn't had its words changed by at least three great-aunts. Tom watched them and felt the odd ache of being held in place by a web of people who could find jokes in seriousness without untying the knot.

Marianne rang on a Wednesday just after he'd retrieved a small pair of wellies from a gutter and was feeling benevolent. "How would you feel about a feature?" she asked, and he nearly dropped the phone because he'd never been asked how he'd feel about a feature before, unless you counted his dentist. It would be a "where are they now" for the regional show in three months, she said, a little piece to check in on his community heroism and perhaps find out whether he had been corrupted by fame. He laughed because he had not, unless you counted buying a second shirt. She laughed back in the way professionals do when they are pleased by an answer that fits a narrative they've already drafted. "We'll call nearer the time," she said, which he now knew translated to, We will call when we need to fill three minutes and we think your face will be kind to our viewers.

The weather turned showy the way spring in Kent likes to, performing four seasons across a morning. One minute the Medway lay polite as a ribbon and the next it shrugged itself brown and busy. He stared down over the railings on the way to work and thought about the line in the song that had made people hum without being asked, and he decided that the river was not any one thing; it was a collection of attempts. He liked being an attempt. Attempts had more room to move in.

Ofsted announced themselves with an email that made the staffroom tilt. Mrs Penney read it aloud in a tone that suggested she could disarm a bomb if asked, and the room made the noises of people recalling the very best bits of themselves at speed. Lists appeared on the whiteboard with arrows that turned into new lists, and everyone said safeguarding to each other in the way people say hello in churches. Tom was handed a stack of policies thick enough to prop up a wobbly table and asked, very nicely but indisputably, to ensure that every door closed as if it had been designed by a manufacturer with a conscience.

"We don't have any time for singing," Mrs Penney told him shortly, which meant she had too much affection to lie. "It is all paperwork and bleaches until Friday. Hide the donkey. The donkey is an Ofsted temptation."

"We could get Outstanding for the donkey alone," he protested mildly. "It has emotional depth."

"It has a nasal cone held on by elastic bands, Mr Merriweather," she said, but she softened it with a glance at the cardboard and the way his hand had absently found the grain of the glue. "All right, the donkey can survive in a neutralised environment. Put a sign on it that says This Is A Placeholder."

The first inspector to stride into St. Pilgrim's had a notebook with corners sharp enough to cut bread and a smile like a polite apology. Tom hovered at the edges of their path with his tool belt cinched and his mop behaving like a soldier at attention. He opened doors for them that had been oiled into compliance and said good morning in five different levels of sincerity because he didn't have time to check which tone matched which person. He liked two of them immediately and decided to be competent in front of the third. He fixed a sudden tantrum in the Year 4 dip taps and stood by in the corridor while the lead inspector stopped at the safeguarding board and nodded in that way that suggested boxes were being gently ticked. The children were unnerved for the first hour and then remembered they had small lives to get on with, which was a relief to everyone.

At breaktime, a girl from the singing club snuck up to him with the stealth of a cat and asked if they would still meet later. "Just humming," she bargained, eyes large, as if humming could be smuggled under the inspection radar. He considered the timetable of the day, the plank of policies, the width of the corridor and his own capacity for mischief, then nodded. "Humming in a whisper," he said, and she grinned like the strike of a match.

They hummed at lunch, nine of them with biscuits they had not technically been allocated by any system that would hold up in court. It sounded like a kettle not quite ready to confess, and it made the gym store feel conspiratorial and safe. He liked that they were doing something gentle and possibly illegal, which is the best category of things in schools if you are careful. When an inspector passed in the corridor and peered in, he raised a hand and said, "Repairing echo," and she smiled properly because she was human and once sang alto in a choir in Cheltenham.

Ofsted left with a verdict that could be described as tidy and the staff drank tea in mugs that had been acquired at summer fetes and glared victoriously at the photocopier as if it were an enemy vanquished. Mrs Penney thanked him in front of people, which she rationed like sugar, and added, as if the universe owed her a balancing clause, that budgets would be a problem by May. He knew what that meant without needing Nina to translate. It meant that positions acquired adjectives like non-essential and discretionary and that sometimes people who knew where things were kept were told to put them down and leave.

He found the mural had been over-painted again when he took his long way home, the YOU ARE GOLD gone in favour of a scrawl that browned at the edges: YOU ARE HERE, which struck him as both either/or and exactly right. The letters sagged a little, but then so did he in the right light. There was a new tag underneath that looked like pool balls scattered in a triangle without the triangle, and he wondered for the first time about the hands that did this under cover of night and whether they ever came to his cake sales.

Mr Dray knocked two evenings after Ofsted had gone as if the inspection had approved his right to appear. He stood with his cough tucked away and his hair trying to remember it existed. "I have a spare forecast," he said, with the formality of someone delivering a family heirloom. "Shipping. I recorded it for my brother who never liked the nights and then he died and I kept the habit, and, well. I've got one left over, if you wanted to see what my living room sounds like." Tom could think of no answer that sounded less than sentimental and more than adequate, so he made tea and carried it upstairs where the carpets muffled worries and the furniture was arranged like it had been given instructions by a person who trusted corners.

They listened to the shipping forecast in the odd reverence it commands if you let it. It had been dropped into the room from another age and sat there smelling of salt you couldn't actually smell. Tom knew the names because he had borrowed them in the nights when he wanted syllables instead of thoughts, but hearing them with Mr Dray had altered the weight of them; Viking, North Utsire, South Utsire, Cromarty, Forties, Bailey, Fair Isle, Faeroes, Southeast Iceland. They were incantations that did not pretend to fix anything but had the decency to try. "I did the radios once," Mr Dray said, eyes on the patch of wall that had been scaffold for a different life. "On ships. Men with hands like spanners saying words into boxes and hoping the air had learned to listen. You can sing at the air if you teach it. Took me too long to work that out."

"I sang to a wall in Tunbridge Wells," Tom confessed, relieved to have a man in front of whom admissions could be made without fuss. "A woman told me I had used space correctly. It felt like being told I'd cut up an onion properly and being moved to tears at the same time."

"You'll be careful," Mr Dray said, in the voice of a man who has deployed his ration of advice in fits and starts across too many years. "The light makes people think they are saints or thieves. Most of us are electricians, really. Wires. Circuits. Fixing the bit that made the thing go dark."

Tom went home from the forecast feeling like he'd been allowed to touch a book in a museum. He slept badly because Ofsted had dislodged a weight he had been using to hold the furniture still, and now things were shifting again. He dreamed of doors with signs on them that changed when he blinked. OPEN morphed to NOT YET and then to WHAT DO YOU THINK YOU'RE DOING and then to PLEASE, which he supposed was a fair representation of his heart.

The day of Goldilocks in Space brought in grandparents who smelt of mints and optimism and siblings whose knees were made of questions. The donkey-ship rolled into the hall with a solemnity nobody had anticipated and then refused to turn left at the point where it was critical to turn left. Tom coaxed it as if it were a nervous dog and the audience clapped in that defusing way people do when a child forgets a line and someone in the third row says, Oh love, and everyone decides to love them. The play was a delightful catastrophe, which is to say it did the important things and none of the unimportant ones. Goldilocks discovered oxygen and sat on a geologically unwise chair and the Captain of the spaceship learned about porridge viscosity, and Tom moved behind the curtains like a man doing small honest miracles and felt himself in his element in the dark.

The cake sale made the corridor smell like every Thursday had decided to stand still and be grateful. The brownies were the kind of sticky that arranges peace treaties, and Gary's card reader failed in ways that made him swear softly and invent new forms of contactless that involved eye contact and hope. An old lady from the hospice appeared with a twenty-pound note that she crisply flattened on the table and a story about a lad in 1978 who had sung Danny Boy during a power cut and made all the babies sleep. By the end of the hour they had raised enough to buy new songbooks and a pack of biscuits that could calm small armies, and Tom took the money to the office with an expression he reserved for carrying hot liquids.

It was in the middle of that small domestic triumph that the email about budgets turned into a meeting that had the feel of a weather warning you could smell. Mrs Penney sat with a document printed on paper that knew it was not enough, and behind it was a table that had borne many hurried lunches and occasional weeps. "We have been asked to model scenarios," she began, which is the sort of sentence that kills appetite. "One of the scenarios is that the caretaker role goes from full-time to half-time. It is not the one I like. It is the one that has been put in front of me by a man with smooth shoes. I am telling you because I prefer to keep loyalty between us and not test it."

He watched the paper in her hands because it was easier than watching her face. He felt the familiar tightening of the day at the edges, the way it does when someone has lifted a glass and you realise it's you and the world will watch to see whether you will spill. "You need a full-time person," he said, hearing the ridiculousness of stating the obvious with a logic that wanted something better than obvious in response. "The pipes don't go part-time and neither does the glue. Children break things on a schedule that mocks calendars. You need two of me most weeks and a spare on Tuesdays."

"I know," she said simply, and there was a fatigue in her voice that was not about sleep. "I will fight for you. I may not win. You will not be blindsided, whatever happens, because I will not have that. There is a possibility in here"—she tapped the sheet as if it were a recalcitrant animal—"about moving you over to the trust's big site as a facilities assistant. It would be more money and less community. I do not know if it's the sort of thing that would keep you upright."

He thought of glass doors and lanyards that didn't have the right weight. He thought of a place where a singing club would be a form to fill rather than a biscuit to share. He thought of the river and the corridor and the janitor's cupboard, which smelt consistently of yesterday and had taught him to trust repetition. "I'll think," he said, and she nodded because she knew that this was his way of shouting.

The mural had acquired a thin figure in chalk when he walked past it that evening, a personified stick man holding a broom like a standard and a speech bubble that declared, WHO CLEANS UP THE STARS. He stopped and laughed, then looked around to see if the artist was leaning nearby, acting like he didn't care. A boy who might have been sixteen with a face that had not yet found a category lurked by the bins, pretending to be married to his phone. Tom held up a thumb and the boy shrugged in that capacious way teenagers have, and then smiled at the ground which, in teenage language, is often a yes.

Nina sent a message that made his phone light up like a sensible promise: Come up Saturday. I have roast. Also a friend I want you to meet who is not a romance, so calm down. He calmed down and said yes and then spent fifteen minutes catastrophising about trains before remembering that people had been catching them before phones had learned tricks. He looked at his bedsit and made a list in his head of the objects he liked as if he were saying goodbye to them, which was absurd and instructive. The teapot. The potato peeler with the nick in the handle. The post-it with his name. The feather in his wallet that hadn't flown but had consented to be carried.

Saturday in Gravesend brought Nina's kitchen, which had been tamed into a place where jars knew their names. She wore an apron as if it owed her money and ignored the roasting pan's complaints. The friend turned out to be a man named Roland who ran something at a community radio station and had hair that had committed to being two styles at once. He talked about microphones as if they were pets and invited Tom to come on a late-night show to talk about songs that had saved people if he wanted, which felt like the kind of temptation you could accept without losing anything you couldn't afford. Nina poured gravy with the determination of a general and told Tom he looked handsome, which in her mouth was almost always a dare to disagree. They ate and argued about trains and he told her about the scenario plan and she swore like a Christian and put more carrots on his plate. After tea, Roland played him the jingles for his show and Tom smiled through them because there are parts of modern life you have to submit to with grace to get to the parts that nourish.

He went home on a train that paused at stations long enough for him to decide if he lived there. He watched small allotments glide by in their diorama earnestness and thought about growing things that didn't ask to be big, which was what he had been trying to do in his cupboard of a life. He fell asleep for six minutes and woke with the picture of a tap in his head and felt a tenderness for it that made him laugh to himself, and the woman across the aisle smiled at him as if she saw the joke.

The week decided to be long and succeeded. On Tuesday the pipe behind the Year 1 cloakroom remembered how to explode and did, and there was a small river down the corridor before Tom could make it into a stream and then into a sulk. He waded in his socks because there wasn't time to bother with anything else and the children watched him like a man in a nature documentary and started to narrate him in whispers. A small boy in wellies asked if this was like the Medway and Tom said yes but nicer, and the boy walked away with the satisfied air of someone who had just had geography become personal. He called the plumber and the plumber was a man who treated emergencies like opportunities for anecdotes, and the two of them got the pipe to stop telling its life story. He wrung his socks out in the sink and felt heroic in the way that matters.

It was that afternoon, while his socks steamed quietly on the radiator in the cleaner's cupboard and he was barefoot in his boots like a fisherman of corridors, that a woman from the trust arrived with an expression like a policy. She wore a coat that didn't crease and smelt of a perfume that tried to be neutral. "Hello," she said, locating him with her eyes as if he had been an item on a list and she was pleased to have found it. "I'm here to have a chat about flexible deployment across the trust estate. Can we talk in your… office?"

"My office is a cupboard," he said, with undefensive pride. "You will have to fold."

She folded elegantly and declined a chair because the chair made excuses. She explained what he already knew in longer sentences, and then she asked the question that had been humming under the others. "How attached are you to Pilgrim's?" she asked, and he tried to answer without the melodrama of a man who writes songs for pipes. He told her the truth, which was that he was attached as a person is attached to the mug he drinks out of every morning, and that sometimes the mug is chipped but your hand has learned the chip and to ask it to accept a saucer would be rude. She looked at him in the way of people who are both taking notes mentally and checking their hair in their head. "We will be pragmatic," she said eventually, which meant nothing and everything. "I appreciate your… local capital."

"Kira says I'm more of a lowercase," he said lightly because it was that or say a thing that would not help either of them. They left it there because sometimes you must, and she took her coat and her smell away and he stood in the cupboard with his socks attempting sainthood and sang one line into the mop so he wouldn't swear.

The radio show with Roland happened on a Thursday that smelt of wet newspaper. The studio was small and industrious and filled with pieces of equipment that had opinions. Roland gave him headphones that made him feel like a man about to be important and a mug that said Tea Before Talent. They talked between songs about the way music makes rooms decide to behave, and people called in with voices that had been softened by midnight. A lorry driver by the Dartford Crossing told him that he sang to stay in his lane when the rain fought him, and a lady called Eileen offered that she had sung to her geraniums for thirty-seven years and nobody had died yet, which must count. Tom sang a little because it would have been rude to turn up and refuse, and the microphone was the forgiving kind that finds something good even in a voice that trembles. When they played the shipping forecast at the end because Roland had found a recording for him, he closed his eyes in a room not built for closing eyes and felt for a moment like all the names belonged to him and none of them stuck.

He expected to be embarrassed at hearing himself when he got home and wasn't, which made him suspect that perhaps he had turned a corner and not noticed. He went up the stairs and paused at Mr Dray's door because the shipping forecast had done that thing where it rearranges the furniture of your chest. He knocked and waited and got nothing. He put his ear to the wood and heard a quiet that was louder than the shipping forecast ever was. He tried the handle because boundaries are real until they're not and found it not locked. He said the man's name the way you do when you don't want to frighten it and walked in.

Mr Dray was on the floor in the place where the carpet had given up long ago, a man who had watched the weather for others and now needed his own weather reported. Tom didn't think of the right things. He thought of tea first because he was English, then he thought of calling the ambulance because he belonged to a century that had taught him a number, and then he was doing both at once and somehow his hand was on the man's shoulder, which felt like a sensible place to put a hand. The phone made its endless questions and he answered like a man who had practised in movies. He spoke in metres and breaths and kept his own voice quiet because there is nothing more panic-making than someone else's panic arriving to join your own.

"Sing," Mr Dray said unexpectedly, his mouth doing the work his chest could not. It wasn't a theatrical request. It was diagnostic. Tom sang because of course he did, not loudly, not the way you sing to rooms, but the way you sing to a baby that hasn't decided about the world yet. He chose something with a tune that didn't ask anyone to climb and made two notes do the work of six. The ambulance came with the displeasure of professionals who have seen too many floors and gathered him up and took him into the night with a speed that felt like rudeness and respect both. Tom followed as far as the curb because men like him don't get to ride in other people's emergencies unless they are invited, and then he stood a long time and watched a patch of tarmac learn silence again.

The hospital smelt like hope and ketchup. He sat in A&E on a chair that had opinions and waited because he had nothing else that would help. A woman with hair like a question mark asked him what the relationship was and he said neighbour and it came out like brother because sometimes that's the same thing. He texted Nina because you text the person who will put the thing into a box you can carry, and she told him to ask for an update every hour even if the desk told him no because the trick with hospitals is to be politely present. He did as he was told and was told very little and considered himself lucky because the telling had not been bad. He went home at three when the receptionist turned the lights up slightly in an attempt to make everyone go home without saying the words, and he slept the way people sleep who have to take their dreams in sips.

He told Kira in the morning and she swore beautifully and made him a coffee that could have done masonry. He told Gary and Gary said he would go and sit in the hospital for him as if waiting could be outsourced, then went anyway because some things are not determined by language. He told Mrs Penney and she was brisk and kind and told him to go in an hour late because she trusted him not to stretch an hour into a day. He went to St. Pilgrim's to tell the mop and the hinges and then he went back to the hospital and found that Mr Dray was mended enough to be cross. They spoke in the way men speak when they intend to cover later with jokes what they feel in the instant. Tom left with a small list in his pocket—milk, bread, a particular kind of apple—the way people leave altars with candles.

There were emails waiting at home because the world is poor at moderating itself. One was from the trust with a preliminary schedule of meetings where his role would become a line weighted by numbers. One was from Marianne with a suggestion of dates in July for a television thing that would require him to be filmed painting a fence he hadn't planned to paint. One was from someone who had seen him on Roland's show and wanted him to sing at a wedding in August in a marquee that would probably pretend to be waterproof. He said yes to the wedding because he liked the idea of singing to love while it tried to dress itself without catching its hem, and he wrote to Marianne to say that if they were going to film him, they could film him moving chairs in a way that would make his back feel seen. He wrote to the trust to thank them for sending the document and asked if he could send them a list of things that go wrong in a week that aren't on a spreadsheet. He did not receive an answer that day, which did not surprise him.

The school summer fete arrived with bunting that looked like arguments settled for the afternoon. There was a tombola manned by a PTA stalwart with eyes like a hawk and a cake stall that had discovered that paper plates were a lie. The caretaker had been asked to set up the tables, then asked to run the tug-of-war, then asked to judge the pet talent show, then asked to be at two places at once and had agreed to all of it with the absent courage of a man who likes to be needed more than he likes the idea of sitting. His singing club had a slot on the small stage that had been borrowed from the Scouts and he had rehearsed them until they were bored and hungry, which was the correct amount. They sang The Water Is Wide because of course they did, and they did it like a group of nine children with wider ranges than their ages, and the parents hummed and so did a man who might have been a distant uncle and so did a woman from the hospice who had come to buy a jar of jam and stayed for a chorus. He looked out and saw not the Assembly Hall but the exact corner of the field where the clover had decided to try again, and he felt, more than thought, that this might be the proper use of his voice.

He went home that night sun-tired and full in that way fetes do to you when the bunting has been taken down and the grass bears the imprint of tables. He put the cash box on the table with its strawberry magnet and its plaque and its feather and it looked like a shrine to small civic duties. He poured himself lemonade and stood at the window and watched the evening do its tidy folding and thought of the teenager with the chalk and the stick man and wanted, quite suddenly, to write on walls. He did not because he was a caretaker and the job is simple and confusing: you clean up after things, but you also decide what mess is worth keeping. He made a list of repairs in his head and it sounded like a song and he laughed out loud because sometimes sentences do that.

It occurred to him, in the days after, that there might be a way to fight for his job that didn't involve shouting at people in coats. He started to gather stories like bolts. He wrote down the time he stopped a pipe from telling secrets to a corridor. He wrote down the afternoon a child who didn't speak much had told him her father sang badly and it made her feel safe. He wrote down the morning he had found a burnt plug just before it could become a lesson in fire and gratitude, the evening he had held a teacher's hand in the storeroom while she pretended not to cry because a relationship had decided to end without consulting her timetable. He wrote down the hum. He wrote down the way corridors were thinner on days when the rain couldn't decide, and how a man with a mop could make them wider. He wrote down that he sang and that some days the song fixed things he couldn't reach. He wrote all of it in his own handwriting because he trusted it more than fonts.

He took the pages to Mrs Penney and put them in front of her like a practical offering. She read and did the thing she does when touched, which is to clear her throat as if there had been dust. "This is not a petition," she said, which puzzled him until she smiled in that two-thirds way that had become their language. "It's better. It's evidence." She took the pages to a meeting and left them there like a helpful ghost. The man with the smooth shoes read and did whatever men with smooth shoes do when confronted by a list of small things that threatened to make their big things look silly. Nothing changed that day. This is not that sort of story. But the shoes might have scuffed at the edges, and in July when the trust proposed the part-time line, a governor who had carried his own list with him to adulthood argued until the letter of offer acquired the phrase to be reviewed in twelve months, which is not much but it lets a man breathe for another winter.

On a Thursday that might have been August, he stood on the bridge and watched the river shrug and thought about water he couldn't name. He had a wedding in a marquee on Saturday and a hospice corridor on the Thursday after and a girl in Year 3 whose mother had promised to bring her on Wednesdays for the club because it had become the thing they shared that didn't cost a miracle. He had the trust meeting in September where his job had to be translated into money in a room that had never met a corridor with a leak. He had Kira at the pub who had started to hum while she polished glasses and stopped apologising for it. He had Gary who pretended the internet didn't matter and then made it do what he wanted when it was useful to him. He had Nina who could turn a roast into a manifesto and had promised to come down for the arts week and heckle gently. He had Mr Dray who had returned to his chair like a man who had reupholstered his existence and now found it adequate, and who had forbidden him, on pain of derisive snort, to bring him a fruit basket.

On his way back past the mural, there was a new phrase, neat and almost shy beside the chalk outlines: YOU ARE HERE, WE ARE HERE. He ran a finger along the R like a man checking that paint had dried and then walked away because the wall did not need him to bless it in public. He went up the stairs to the bedsit and the hinges congratulated him for not falling down and he sang one verse to the teapot and one to the mop and one to the part of himself that still thought he needed permission. He lay on his bed and looked up at Norway and thought about what to do with the next long corridor the world would offer him, and he slept before the answer had a chance to make a mess.

The wedding was on a farm with a marquee that sweated lightly and an aunt who had commandeered the buffet with an energy that suggested she had been waiting her whole life for her canapé moment. The bride had a laugh that did not ask anyone to behave and the groom cried in a way that improved his face. Tom sang where he could be useful, which was at the bit between speeches and dancing when people's attention wanders like sheep. He sang The Water Is Wide because the couple had asked for a folk song and then, because the bride's grandfather had requested it in a voice that could still turn a room, he sang a verse of The Parting Glass, which he had once thought belonged to other people but discovered, in that moment, belonged to anybody willing to mean it. The tent breathed and the fairy lights considered him without judgement and a child fell asleep under a table and he felt tired in his spine and happy in his feet. He took his envelope money with embarrassment and then accepted it like a grown man accepts pay, and he gave half of it to the hospice on Monday because he'd promised himself that when he earned with his throat he would pay his debt to the corridor.

By the end of summer the singing club had a song of their own about St. Pilgrim's that rhymed glue with through in a way that redeemed both words. They had asked to perform it at assembly and had been advised by Mrs Penney that the world was not yet prepared, and then she booked them for five minutes on the last day anyway, which is how she does kindness without denting her reputation. They made posters by hand because printers are not to be trusted, and Kira came in her day clothes and Gary stood at the back pretending to fix a socket and Mr Dray sat in the aisle with his radio ear turned on, and for five minutes a school hall tilted toward the right. After, in the corridor, the children said thank you in voices that didn't quite know where to put their new bigness and Tom said you're welcome in a way that didn't make a fuss, and Sandra cried because she does and then laughed at herself because she also does that.

September went back on, as it always does, like a cardigan that smells of pencil cases and rain. The trust meeting happened in a room that had a carpet designed to dissuade comfort and a water cooler that made confidential noises. He brought his pages and his stories and his list of repairs and wore his shirt that had been careful for him in Tunbridge Wells. They discussed headings and figures and the meaning of essential and in the end the compromise was a promise dressed in a formality; he would stay in place with the threat of being redistributed hovering like weather, and there would be a review, and he would be invited to contribute to the long-term facilities plan as if his hands had been suddenly noticed by the plan's eyes. He left with fatigue that wrapped itself around his ribs and with a small laminated card that asserted his expertise, which he put in his wallet next to the feather because both things needed safe keeping.

He walked home along the river because even when life is mercilessly practical, the Medway will do you a favour if you let it. The water was not doing anything impressive and he loved it for that. He breathed and tilted his head like a man listening for train announcements and heard only air that had been through lungs before, and he was grateful. He turned towards Finnerty's and the bedsit and the shipping forecast that would declare its small sovereignties later and the doors at St. Pilgrim's that would swing tomorrow without taking offence, and he thought, with a steadiness that surprised him, that whatever having a chapter meant, he had one and it was his to keep or misplace as he liked. He decided to keep it, and he decided to keep it with other people, and the decisions, for once, felt like turning a screw until it held and knowing when to stop.Autumn fell into its habit of pretending to be winter early, the way some people try out a haircut before they've made up their minds. The Medway wore a shawl of mist that didn't keep it warm, and the mornings had a crispness that made keys drag on their ring like old bones. St. Pilgrim’s returned to its palette of navy and grey and mud, and the corridors remembered how to smell of wet coats and ambition. Tom swore he could hear the building brace, small adjustments in pipes and frames as if an orchestra had lifted instruments to their chins and settled before the first note. He did the same with his day. The singing club met on Wednesdays in the gym store and on Thursdays wherever there was a plug that hadn't been claimed by a laminator, and in between he fixed things with the devotional cheer of a man who has given up on miracles and begun to trust ritual.

The mural had been repainted decisively and then embellished sheepishly. YOU ARE HERE had sprouted a neat additional pronoun: WE. Beneath it the stick man with the broom had been joined by a stick woman with a bucket and a crown, and somebody had drawn a figure with a microphone and a key ring the size of Saturn. Tom took this as evidence that the teenager with the phone and the surrogate shrug had either been busy or had acquired allies. He began to look for the boy deliberately on his way home and found him twice and pretended, both times, that he was not looking. Their conversation blossomed the way teenage conversations do with adults they have not yet decided are police: sideways, over time, and with an emphasis on weather.

"You draw?" Tom asked eventually, in a tone he reserved for questions he was willing to watch die ungathered.

"I design," the boy replied, without arrogance. "I only draw when the wall's right. Can't waste lines on bad wall."

"That wall's had so many coats it ought to have a winter wardrobe," Tom said. "I'm Tom. I fix things."

"Jay," the boy offered after an appraisal that lasted a beat longer than comfort. "I make them worse and then prettier. The council hates me in the abstract and uses my photos to look current. It's all right. Everyone has to be a hypocrite somewhere."

"You want to paint scenery that won't wash off in the rain?" Tom asked, surprising them both with the speed of the offer. "Year 2's got space left in its galaxy, and my donkey is holding out for his close-up."

Jay's mouth did something that might have been almost a smile before he remembered himself and stole the expression back. "Yeah. Maybe. Paper lies beautifully if you treat it right. I could make your stars for you. And your planets. Proper rings, not those stupid hula-hoops people do."

"Done," Tom said, as if he had just signed a treaty that would bring peace to a corridor.

The trust wrote to say that the review would be in twelve months and that the phrase flexible deployment would acquire a working definition, which is the kind of future that doesn't fit nicely into a mind. Tom printed the email because he wanted to hold it in his hands and feel its unhelpfulness. He folded it and unfolded it and put it under the strawberry magnet, then took it down because the magnet made it look like something you keep on a fridge to keep hope fresh. He wrote instead on a card the sentence Nina had given him to memorise and kept forgetting: There will be another day to fight, and perhaps a better one. He placed that under the magnet and found the strawberry's frivolity reassuring.

The weather pivoted in a way that had not been announced in any forecast Mr Dray had played for him. Rain practiced for two days and then turned up to see what it could get away with. The river swelled and walked itself up the banks like a visitor who had found the spare key. The school whispered about sandbags, the way people whisper about old flames, half disapproving and half eager for the drama. Tom spent a morning in the caretaker’s cupboard making piles make sense, putting torches with batteries and batteries with their right friends, checking that the mop heads were not planning mutiny. He took delivery of three dozen grey sacks with a willingness that startled the man who had to carry them and wrote sand with a marker on them in letters that were too neat.

It began with a trickle in the playground where the drain had never quite learned its lesson. It continued with a suggestion of damp where the Year 1 corridor joined the cloakroom, and then the suggestion became declarative. At eleven, a teacher whose calm had been made in a forge knocked on the cupboard door and told him that the river had decided to make an appearance by the back gate. He stepped outside into air that had gone greenish with worry and saw the water testing the school like a burglar checks windows. He called the council with the efficient despair of someone who had called them before and then he called Gary because if you wanted something turned into a temporary solution with a lifespan of six hours and a story to dine out on, you called Gary.

By noon the world smelled of wet cardboard and effort. He and two TAs who had known him long enough to mimic his jokes built a low defence that looked like ambition and hope had been translated into grey. The children ate lunch in classrooms because the hall was flirting with puddles, and there was a hum in the building that was not singing and not panic but a third thing that coordinates bodies without arguing with hearts. Kira arrived with a flask the size of a small moon and six cups that had once been mismatched and were now, through use, a set. Gary brought a dehumidifier on a dolly and swore that he had bartered it for a bag of 10p pieces and a favour owed from a man who had no name, which meant he had bought it in cash from a man named Stuart. Mrs Penney moved along the corridors with her hands in her pockets the way a general keeps his behind his back, seeing the whole.

At one, the water asked for more and the sky gave it. The back classrooms looked out on a new pond and the sound altered in a way that made everyone 5% more aware of their knees. Tom lifted chairs like he was rescuing cats and thought not at all about what would happen if water decided to be a tenant. He spoke to doors and meant it; Keep this line, he said to one that had always fancied itself a leader. Be the hero you were made to be, he said to another that squeaked when nervous. He didn't sing because singing tears the membrane that keeps calm intact and he needed that membrane today, but he hummed a line that had nothing to do with rivers and everything to do with not dropping things. Jay turned up in a hoodie that had aspirations and calm on his face, looked at the river, and shrugged in an appraising way. "I can get pallets," he said. "From behind Aldi. They owe me for art. I’ll build you a catwalk."

They built a catwalk, because of course they did, and for an hour the school walked on wood and felt like a ship remembering itself. In Year 3, a child decided to test physics by crying loudly enough to cause weather, and Tom sat on a low chair and explained that rain was not personal and that sometimes water needed to see other places and would return, and the child doubted him correctly and then put her head on his knee as if she had chosen to trust the chair instead. When, at two, the headteacher from across town rang to see how they were managing, Mrs Penney stood in the office and said words that would reassure a person who needed to be told that the world could still be organised, and Tom watched her and felt a surge of admiration for a woman who could tell reality how to behave respectfully.

The water stopped where it was supposed to stop. It considered an inch, had the grace to think about it, and then held. The day lengthened in the particular way days do when they have been asked to hold a little too much. Parents came early and later, depending on the river and the buses, and the school became a cloakroom for anxieties and umbrellas. Tom lifted children over the last mind of water and made a joke about pirates until it became boring and then stopped because there is nothing more infuriating than a person who continues to be funny after the joke has retired. At three-thirty, when the bell sounded like it was working for its living, the corridor hum happened again, unbidden, in the place where the floor had dried and the light made a rectangle on the tiles. He stood in it with his key ring heavy in his hand and didn't sing because it would have been theatre, and instead he checked the sandbags with the gravity of a man who has invented a new hobby.

When the last child had been claimed and the last teacher had sighed in relief and guilt, they sat in the staffroom with tea and the high of getting away with something. Gary discovered biscuits somewhere and rationed them with cruel wisdom. Kira took off her eyeliner with a tissue like a flag of surrender and tucked her feet under her as if she had been born to that sofa. Jay hovered near the door and pretended to look at his phone and then sat because nobody told him not to. Mrs Penney said thank you without frill and without calling it anything else, which made the thank you weigh the right amount. Tom looked at his hands and found them river-dirty and good for nothing except more useful things, and he felt tired in the way men feel tired when they have done the thing they can do and kept something from breaking that didn't have to break that day.

That night the Medway sulked and then pretended it had never had ideas above its station. The world outside the bedsit smelled of clean-up, that particular odour of defeat and victory mixed. Tom washed his hands for longer than necessary and the water seemed to forgive him for having sworn at it earlier. He knocked on Mr Dray's door out of habit born of the day's edges, and the older man opened wearing the cardigan that had had to learn his shape. They listened to the forecast together without speaking because sometimes you borrow another man's habit to put your own away. Cody, Fitzroy, Biscay, German Bight, the names came, more confident and less wet than they had any right to be given the evidence outside. When it was done, Mr Dray coughed with dignity and pointed his chin at the wall. "Never trust a low that calls itself manageable," he said, and Tom laughed with such relief he worried he would cry.

Jay turned up the next day with a roll of paper that had been saved from a bonfire and an authority over tape that would have impressed the council. He had brought two friends who behaved like apprentices in a guild they didn't know they'd joined. They filled the stage with a galaxy that wasn't real but could be believed by anyone who looked up tired after a day of adding and subtracting. Jay worked fast, the kind of fast that comes from not planning and having planned secretly for months, and he let Tom cut stars while making conversation an optional extra. At the end, when the donkey-ship rolled out through a field of perfect planets, Jay made a sound that could have been approval and photographed it like he was stealing a moment to sell later to himself in a poorer mood.

"You do singing," he said then, as if the information had been presented and verified by a third party. "I don't sing. I draw loud, though."

"You drew us a sky," Tom said. "Always handy for a song."

"You're weird," Jay said, with accuracy and something like fondness, then tightened the tape on a corner and disappeared in the way teenagers can when the room thinks it has more time to say the right thing.

The Wednesday singing club doubled because children have a nose for good rooms. It was still only twelve, but it felt like a choir if you squinted and believed. They stood among the vaulting poles and the crash mats and made a sound that understood the space. Tom printed out lyrics with a font that refused to apologise and introduced a new song because a club needs to believe it can produce novelty or it will lose momentum like a bike that has decided to become a chair. He had written it in his head while counting sandbags because that was when the mind agreed to multitask, and it was about hinges, because of course it was, and about doors that know your name and about the particular mercy of a corridor that curves and still gets you somewhere. The children laughed when the door got a line, and then they sang it carefully because laughing and careful often travel together in the young.

He wrote to Marianne when the rain had given up, because the television people had begun their sniffing for feel-good, and told her about the river and the sandbags and the pallets from behind Aldi and the catwalk and the hum, and suggested gently that if the region liked people who were part of their places, perhaps their cameras could point at the people who had done the saving with their quieter hands. Marianne phoned the next day, sounding as if she had enjoyed putting something obvious over a small flame for just long enough to call it cooking. She said she wanted to send a crew to film the singing club and the painted stars, and he said all right, but that the club was not television-friendly in the way shows like; it was full of small pauses and jokes that require context and biscuits. She laughed and said biscuits are universally legible and promised no staged humming. He believed her because she knew what he meant about the light making people think the wrong things were important.

The hospice wrote on paper with a logo that had flowers that managed to be sincere, and asked whether, at the Christmas fair, he would sing while the raffle destroyed the flow of time, because people are gentler with their money when there are carols. He had a complicated relationship with carols because they were songs he had learned at an age when he thought songs came with rules for being a person and things had deteriorated afterwards, but he said yes because the corridors there had held him up when he leaned, and because he wanted to be the kind of man who sang between mince pies and a secondhand jigsaw. He told Nina, who told him not to be manipulated by anyone with tinsel, and then said she would come and wear a jumper that could light a village.

November brought a cold that didn't announce itself with sneezing so much as with the increasing unwillingness of batteries. The hall lights took half a second longer to remember their brilliance, and the photocopier, which was powered by demons and acronyms, demanded sacrifice. Tom oiled and buffed and tightened and discovered a new squeak in the Year 2 cupboard that sounded like a toy horse confessing, and he found himself liking it because it was a noise he could solve. He bought plasters with cartoons on for a child who had become fascinated by the edges of doors and the consequences of distraction. He taped up a poster for the Christmas fete that had been designed by someone enthusiastic about clip art and considered writing 'and music' under 'mulled wine' with a pen, then decided that smugness is often the enemy of community and let the poster be.

He went to Gravesend two Sundays in a row because Nina needed him to build a shelf and because she had a cackle that improved roast potatoes. Roland came round with an armful of records and a suggestion that Tom come back on the radio to talk about songs people share at funerals, which was either ghoulish or practical and possibly both. Tom agreed because it would mean saying out loud things that people say to him in corridors and bringing them into a room where everyone could pretend to be alone together. He helped Nina put the shelf up and pretended to know how to use a spirit level with more confidence than he had, and when it was done she looked at it and declared it useful and then hugged him in the manner of a person who is fixing something that cannot be fixed but wants to mark attendance.

The day the television crew came back for their small where-are-they-now, the school smelled of glitter glue and new cardigans. The producer with the ponytail turned up with ginger biscuits which meant she had been promoted by a minor god. They filmed the club from a respectable distance and caught Keir making a beat under The Water Is Wide that was inappropriate and perfect, and they recorded Jay painting a small comet on a corner nobody would film properly, and no one told him not to because the law of classrooms is that a boy with paint can be contained by kindness more efficiently than by rules. Marianne asked if Tom would sing a bit to camera and he said he would hum if the room did, and then the room hummed and the camera looked pleased because it had caught an accident behaving itself.

It was in the middle of that humming that the trust woman arrived again, smelling of compromise and good handbags. She stood in the doorway and watched for ten seconds longer than was necessary and then caught herself and began speaking in bullet points. The review had been pushed to spring because budgets had decided to become pumpkins at midnight and the trust wanted to see how winter was going to treat the pipes, she said, turning even water into an agenda item. She spoke about estates strategy and the need to develop talent across sites, and he heard the irony and decided to step into it.

"Let me teach caretakers how to listen to buildings," he said, surprising himself with the audacity of suggesting anything that wasn't defensive. "Let me run a morning somewhere with a room of people with mops and give them a list of tricks that aren't on the spreadsheet. How to make a door behave without breaking its pride. How to speak to radiators in a language they respect. How to get chalk off walls without making the wall give up. How to be part of a school without being swallowed."

She blinked because it is not every day a man with glue on his cuffs presents you with a curriculum. "We don't have budget for training," she began, by reflex, and then stopped because there was a camera capturing a humming that might make donors feel generous at breakfast. "But we do have staff conference day in February. I'll put you on, if you send me a title that makes it sound like we meant it all along."

"Care of Fabric," he said immediately, because he'd been giving his sessions the names he wished buildings had. "Fabric meaning cloth and thread and bodies. Fabric meaning walls and doors. Care meaning both. I'll bring biscuits. No PowerPoint. Just hands."

She laughed despite the part of her that wanted to be immune to charm and wrote it down, and later he would tell Gary that the first lesson in advocacy is to wait until a person is standing near a camera and then suggest a thing that sounds like you've only just thought of it even if you've been rehearsing for days.

December found him at the hospice with a song list that he had made the way you make tea for unexpected company. He sang carols without making them fancy because some songs don't appreciate your embroidery. He did Once in Royal not because he had loved it as a child but because his mother had sung the alto line over the top by accident, and because he liked the way the third verse let you breathe. He sang The Parting Glass because a woman with a hat that had seen war asked for it and because the room had needed a song that didn't square its shoulders. He sang the hinge song because a child had gravitated toward the keyboard and hit middle C with dogged devotion, and the hum happened in the corridor without him asking and he watched the nurse with the forget-me-not touch her wrist as if the flower had warmed. Nina wore a jumper with a reindeer that blinked and shouted at him in whispers when he had almost cried near the raffle table, which is what you pay sisters for.

Back at St. Pilgrim’s, the Christmas production arrived like a bus that had been expected at four and rolled in at half past five with apologies and a horn. There were shepherds with attitudes and angels with hair decisions and a donkey whose ship had learned to turn left if coaxed in a voice that promised biscuits later. Jay's stars glittered under lights they had not been designed for and got away with it. The singing club stood at the side and discovered a new talent for being ready and then waiting, and Tom stood behind the curtain and held his breath while the Year 2 narrator declared that space was like a porridge you had to stir with a rocket and was pummelled gently by three grandmothers who could not cope with the logic. The audience clapped in the right places and laughed in the wrong places and loved everything because everything had been made by hands they recognised. After, in the hall, Tom mopped glitter with a resignation that had learnt to be fond, and told the door that had been the hero that it had performed beyond specifications and would be thanked appropriately with oil in January.

That night, upstairs, Mr Dray produced from a drawer a Morse key that had been kept alive by tea and habit. He placed it on the table with a reverence that made the lamp stand still. "I can't use it anymore without dragging ghosts up with it," he said, flatly and without pleading, "but it ought to be used or it will sulk, and sulky instruments haunt houses. Learn it. Or take it to your club and let them pretend to be ships at sea. Teach them what a dot feels like. Teach them how to ask for help with a finger."

Tom took it the way you take a small animal someone trusts you with and found that holding it made his back straighten. He tapped once, twice, idiotically, and Mr Dray made a face that a better friend would have anticipated and softened. He showed him the rhythm for S and O with a patience that made the table like him more. They sat and tapped, and the room became a room where other men had sat and tapped and hoped for ears, and Tom thought about rhythm as a kind of watching that makes sound behave.

The singing club learned Morse in the way children learn anything under the guise of drama. They sent messages across the crash mats with their fingers like spies whose passwords are biscuits, and Tom didn't tell them that one day they might need to tell a room they were not all right without frightening their own voices, because that was not a thing you teach in a gym store. He asked Jay to paint them a simple code on the back of a piece of scenery, and Jay wrote dots and dashes with the precision of a man who enjoyed systems but only in private and only if they could be defaced later for art. Keir, who had been born with a rhythm machine where other boys store their disinclination to tidy, tapped a backbeat under SOS and then had the grace to stop when Amara gave him a look that could cut wire.

Two days before term ended, the trust sent round a flyer for the staff conference day in February with a schedule that had been assembled by a person who believed in verbs. Care of Fabric sat at eleven o'clock in a font that did not apologise for itself next to sessions on trauma-informed pedagogy and teaching maths through dance, which made Tom both proud and anxious for the world. Nina rang to say that she had found a secondhand suit for a tenner and would be bringing it down because you ought to have something that makes you walk differently for days like that, and he told her he would consider his walking and she told him he had better consider it out loud where she could hear. Kira threatened to stand at the back with a placard that read HE'S FUNNY REALLY and Gary offered to heckle with love and then, unexpectedly, told him he wasn't allowed to fail because he'd already bought a notebook for the quotes.

On the last morning before the holidays, he arrived at St. Pilgrim’s to find a note in the pigeonhole that had not come through the usual channels. It was folded over neatly and had his name in pencil in a hand that made its letters sit up straight. Inside there was a drawing of the corridor rectangle of light and a cartwheel that somebody had smudged with a thumb, and underneath, in their new careful writing, the words Thank you for the hum. It was not signed because sometimes thank yous don't need to be attached to a throat to be true. He stood in the cupboard and held it and thought about the part of his job that would never go on a spreadsheet and never make it into a policy and never be used as evidence when the trust brought its forms to town, and he thought about the day in February when he would be allowed to tell other caretakers to listen to walls, and he felt a closeness to himself that was not vanity but something that resembled fidelity.

The mural had changed again, because the wall never allowed itself boredom. WHO CLEANS UP THE STARS had acquired an answer written in a different hand: WE DO, WITH OUR COATS ON. It made him laugh in the street in a way that made two older ladies turn and approve. He reached out and touched the edge of the chalk R with one finger as if checking if a cake was done and then thought about telling Jay and decided not to because some compliments were better overheard than delivered. He went into The Oast House because Kira had told him there would be sausage rolls only fit for men who had faced rivers, and found her and Gary and two TA's and a parent governor and the postman and a child who had won a raffle prize he couldn't carry, and for half an hour he sat and let other people talk while he ate, and the grindcore of the coffee machine tried to fight the hum of the room and failed because this was a place that had been taught by use how to hold sound without bruising.

In his bedsit that night he laid the Morse key on the table next to the feather and the plaque and the strawberry magnet's stubborn cutesiness, and the arrangement looked like a museum of a person who had found uses for both the beautiful and the blunt. He tapped S, O, S like a man checking whether a song worked upside down, and then he tapped, tentatively, OK in the code he had been taught by a man who had made himself into radio, and there was a sense in the room that something had answered. He laughed at himself and put the key away in a drawer with a reverence that was only half pretending, and then he lay on his bed and looked at Norway and thought about flood water and the sound children's humming had made in the corridor and the way sandbags can persuade a river to consider its options, and he slept because it had been earned.

Christmas did its capable thing and moved on, leaving behind oranges with redundant cloves and strings of lights that had become discussions. January walked in with its hands in its pockets and the wrong shoes, and the school returned with a cheer that was at once real and minimal. He stood at the doors on the first day back and told them they were beautiful, because he had promised himself to do it on days when it was not obvious. The hinges responded with a confidence he chose to attribute to compliments rather than new oil, and the hall, when he switched on the lights, chose to cooperate without drama. In the gym store, the crash mats waited with the stoicism of soldiers, and he felt sudden gratitude for things that keep their shape when asked to more than usual.

On the second Wednesday of term he brought the Morse key to the club and told them they were going to learn to say hello and I'm here and can you hear me and sorry, not yet, and somebody asked if there was a code for biscuit and he told them he'd invent one. They tapped and giggled and tapped like people inventing a language that adults would feel left out of, and he found himself thinking that if he had been given this small instrument at nine he might have stayed in certain rooms longer, or at least not blamed them for failing to notice he was in them. He glanced at the doorway and found Jay leaning there, pretending to look for attention and finding it, and asked if he'd paint them a code to keep, and Jay nodded as if asked to memorialise something the council would never read.

When he walked home that night the river behaved itself and the air had given up on being dramatic. He paused on the bridge because he didn't like letting days turn into other days without consent, and watched the water look like a difficult essay that had finally been handed in. He thought about February and the staff conference and about the trust's careful vocabulary and about the boy in Year 3 who had lost a tooth in assembly and held it up like a white flag and about a woman at the hospice who had sung three words with him and then stopped because that had been exactly enough. He thought about what he could tell other caretakers that would not feel like showing off and would not be a waste of their tea, and it occurred to him quite calmly that he had a thing somebody else might need. He held the thought as if it were a bolt he intended to put down somewhere safe, and then he went home and told the doors goodnight, and the doors said nothing, and he trusted them.

The first bus out of Tonbridge groaned past the river, the driver drumming his fingers on the wheel like he was keeping time with something only he could hear. The grey light threw up low shimmers from the Medway, and the swans looked like badly folded napkins dotted along the water. On Quarry Hill Road, the shop shutters shivered awake. One by one: a fishmonger with a fractured green sign, the charity shop that smelt of lavender and dust and bright wool, the carpet place with the display rolled up like the tongues of dragon dogs. On the corner, a half-dead tree scratched a page of sky. You could almost smell toast, if you wanted it enough.

Tom Merriweather walked to work with a key ring like a small planet orbiting his palm. He was thirty-eight and had a face people said was trustworthy when they'd lost something. He had shoulders that sloped like he'd grown used to carrying poles, planks, ladders, children who'd fallen, guilt about leaks. He worked at St. Pilgrim’s Primary, a practical building that never decided if it wanted to be hopeful or petty, and after ten years he could listen to the walls and know which was about to peel.

He talked to the doors. "Morning, you." The doors never answered, but responded in a way, the way a door does: swinging more easily for people who wag fair words at them.

The custodian's cupboard smelt of mop and medicinal soap and yesterday. He clicked the light, listened to the whirr of the fixture warming up—half a second, then the blossom of humming. It sounded, in his better moods, like the beginning of a song. He sang to himself because it made the mops dance and the broom handles softened their hard stares. He had a voice that, to him, seemed to enter a room half a beat before he did.

It was an old song he favoured this morning, something his mum used to hum while shelling peas—Molly Malone, poor girl, or the one about a river that was never the same river twice. He liked the way the vowels lifted like kites and then went slack on their strings. He liked imagining that they could fly to a place where he fit. He ran the mop along the assembly hall like a man sweeping a stage, paused to look at his own reflection in the polished wood and saw one of those faces that can't keep still. He hit a note at the ceiling and held it longer than the light held its breath.

"Again?" Mrs Penney said from the doorway. She was somewhere between stern and soft, and wore shoes that knew where they wanted to go.

Tom straightened, the mop head dangling. "Keeps the acoustics exercised." He tried a joke like he always did.

She smiled with only two thirds of her mouth. "The sound system keeps the acoustics exercised. You've the caretaker's cupboard today. Leaking bleach. And the Year 2 play equipment hasn't come, so be a magician."

He pulled the mop upright like a soldier. "Righto, righto. You want me to build a donkey or a spaceship?"

"Both. It’s Goldilocks in space this year. Budget cuts. And—" She hesitated, turned, decided against whatever she was about to say, then decided for it. "Keep the singing for after three, will you? They're doing tests. And you know some of them complain."

"Who complains?"

"Parents. Mostly. The children like you. Or they like the idea of you." She left on that odd note, and Tom felt an old bruise of embarrassment bloom at his collar.

"You can't shush a river," he murmured. He did not sing again, which was not the same thing as stopping.

He liked the little jobs that nobody noticed. There was a satisfaction in the quiet heroism of a hinge that no longer squeaked. He took the box of screws from the toolbox, lifting handfuls like pistachios, cupping each tiny head between finger and thumb and turning, turning, until it bit and held. He was good at turning until things held. He was less good at knowing when to stop.

At break, a group of boys gathered by the back step and watched him wind the hose onto its reel. The newest one, a small boy with a forehead like a cliff, asked, "Sir, why do your eyes sing when your mouth does?" Which was nonsense strictly speaking, but true in a way Tom liked more.

"You hear with more than your ears," Tom said. "Watches can hear time pass you know."

"That's just ticking," said a sensible boy with a tight mouth.

"Ticking is sighing for machines." Tom winked and the small cliff nodded as if he'd deciphered something.

They asked him to sing. He shook his head toward the staffroom window, where a silhouette moved dangerously like a teacher with opinions, and he sang anyway, but quietly. "When I was one-and-twenty..." The boys leaned in, mown-grass smell, scabby knees, a chorus of the bored and the fervent. Halfway through, the sensible boy giggled and then they all did, a ripple moving through them like a fish. Tom smiled and finished the verse. After they ran away, he looked up to see his own reflection in the staffroom window, mouth open, eyes partly closed. It wasn't pretty. He decided it looked serious.

His phone vibrated like an insect in his pocket at lunch. He ate in the little cafe beyond the station some days, but more often he went to The Oast House, which had learned his name without asking. Kira, who worked the noon shift and wore eyeliner as if it were armour, poured him a pint of lemonade without asking, and placed it in front of him like a truce.

"You singing tonight, Tom?" she asked. She was used to the question stealing the lift from her eyebrows when she saw the way he lit.

"Not formally," he said. "But I will if conjured. I'm thinking of—"

"Please don't say My Way."

"—My Way." He grinned at her as if he had done something clever.

"You know the contest?" Kira nodded at a poster pinned near the back door, where it would attract exactly as much attention as a notice about a missing cat. SOUTH EAST SONG QUEST, it read, a star and musical notes climbing a ladder. Heat from the kitchen had curled one corner. The paper looked as though it was tired of making promises.

Tom's eyes landed like magpies. "Is that—" He got up too quickly and his lemonade sloshed.

"That's old," Kira said over the clink of plates. "Came last year, I think. The bloke never collected the posters. They do a new one every spring. You can go to Tunbridge Wells and stand in a queue and two minutes later they'll tell you what you've got. Or not. It was funny last time. There was a man did Blackbird who sounded like one."

"Blackbird's easy to confuse," Tom said gravely, closer to the paper than any grown man should need to be. The print had been smudged so the dates smudged with it. A tear-off strip had only one ragged number left: 0777something, the rest lost to time or teenagers.

"There's more online," Kira said. "It's always online."

"I don't have the online." He said it lightly, in case it was a confession.

"You don't have the online?" She laughed the way she did, an unexpected delighted sound like dice in a cup. "You don't have a phone?"

"I have a phone. It's a phone that phones. It's... a talking machine."

"Eyes to floor, Granddads," she teased. "Well, maybe you get a leaflet from the library. Or ask Gary. Gary has everything. He's a mole with Wi-Fi."

"I'll ask Gary," he said, pocketing the poster tab, though it lacked the piece a person would need. He liked the feel of torn paper. He liked talismans.

He ate his shepherd's pie in a daze, counted out the coins, and left a chip in neat halves, because leaving a whole would be wasteful, and eating it would be greed.
